reviewText:
Early Access Review

Return of the Patriarch + Microtransaction thoughts below the review!
It's been a long time coming, and was it worth the wait?

Oh yes, it was.
I loved the first Killing Floor, so I was very excited to see a second one. While I normally do not buy into these early access titles, how could I say no to Tripwire?

So, let's get started.

The Gameplay
At the writing of this review, there is currently 4 classes with about 4 weapons for each, as well as a few off-perk weapons like the Katana or the Flamethrower. You can use ANY weapon at any time, just like the first. The weapon you use will give you points for that class, so say you have a medic pistol with a commando rifle? You will be able to rack up points for medic using the healing function whilst using the rifle to earn yourself the commando points. ZED time is still prominant, and it is so, so satisfying. The visuals will run into a sin-city like look, with only red standing out amongst the black, gray and white filtered backgrounds and characters. Most weapons have a reasonably large amount of kick, but this further emphasizes the need to have trigger discipline.

What makes it different from the first?
At the moment, you can see the obvious. The graphics upgrade, the animations, and of course the enviroment designs. However, in this game there are tons of small things that all compile into what sets this game apart. You can shoot out lights, blood is persistent, and there are TONS of different animations, both for players and zeds. Enemies flinch when shot, and it varies heavily on what weapon you are using. Shooting a clot in a shoulder with a pistol will only make him flinch a tiny bit, but upping the ante and shooting him in the chest with a rifle will cause him to violently flail backwards and nearly lose his balance. You can shoot off several parts of their body, head wounds will start small and slowly wear their flesh away until there is only a meaty remnant that looks nothing like what it once did until that satisfying head pop. Everything, and I mean EVERYTHING feels much more alive and less clunky than the first, from the reload animations to the death animations.

Should you buy into it?
At it's current state, it's hard to say. You will get 4 perks and limited weaponry, with only 3 maps to spare. As it stand, there is much more content in the first game. However, if you buy into the early access, you are not only supporting Tripwire, but you give yourself a chance to watch this game bloom. You get to experience a game that has lots of love in it, and you can see that Tripwire cares about this game. Yes, it has bugs. Yes, there are glitches. No, there is no buyers remorse from me. If you expect a full game, you may want to lower your expectations, but this is certainly not a bad way to start off a early access game.

The Characters
Wow. You have about 10 characters at the moment, including a female one. These characters are all unique, and have their own voices. They will talk a LOT, and this is not a bad thing. They will call out ammo, kevlar, and weapons. They will talk to each other with idle banter whilst you're shopping at the trader, and they will also pitch a few jokes. There are a few stereotypes, but it adds to the quirky and goofy traits they all have, and they even have things you can add to them, like gas masks or face masks. You can also change their clothing colour, hair colour and a few other neat features absent in the first game.

The Zeds
There are 3 different clots, and so far I don't see much of a difference between them. However, they behave much like the same game, spare their animations. They will oftentimes hold you just as that gorefast is charging, or the fleshpound is roid raging. The gorefasts move fast, and are tall hulks that you do NOT want to get close to. The siren is short and blends into groups, often hiding behind clots or bigger enemies. The stalkers are nearly invisible, and are disturbingly quiet. The skrakes and fleshpounds make roars when they enter, that strikes that scene of oh no" into you. And the final boss is HARD. This game makes the zeds feel more alive than ever

and I love every second of it.

My final thoughts
All in all

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Alright, for those of you who HAVE played KF1, I'll get to you a little bit later, promise.

As for the newcomers, Killing Floor 2 is simply the best wave-based horde FPS game out there.
The gameplay flows smoothly, the graphics are nothing to sneeze at and it's challenging. Currently (Early Access), you get 4 perks (classes) to choose from and level up - each with their own playstyle, pros and cons. Despite clearly being at it's best and based around co-op gameplay, you can also play solo - perfectly viable too as it gets 'rebalanced' for it.


Now for the veterans of KF1 such as myself, we start with an important question. Is it an improvement? Yes!! Yes it is. Remember how going up in difficulty was nothing but numbers? The Zed's HP, speed and damage would increase while the player's money gain and item pickups would decrease? Welp, those days are over (for the most part ;D ).
In KF2, the difficulty increase respects the weapons and players - no longer turning Zeds into bullet sponges as they keep the exact same HP as in any lower difficulty. Now the real threat is how they become more aggressive and behave differently (i.e. - jumping and dodging) which makes it even harder than the previous game.

Another great aspect is that using weapons from other perks is now -very- viable due to the new difficulty system and the perk level bonuses not being too focused on their own weapon category.

Leveling is now XP based instead of meeting specific criteria, so no more AFK welding for the Support Specialists! And the levels now go up to 25, making it feel a bit less grindy since you level up more often.
Each 5 levels you also gain a skill point to spend in one of two choices for that tier (i.e. - Commando gets to choose between higher damage or faster reload).

All in all, this game is a must buy for the new players and veterans alike despite still being in Early Access!

Early Access Review

**Review is from the closed beta, will update on later versions*

Killing Floor 2, like its predecessor, is my kind of multiplayer game. It's a class-based co-operative shooter where you're pitched against wave after wave of increasingly powerful zeds, and if you manage to survive that, the map boss will likely eat you alive. Money is earned for both kills and performing actions relevant to your perk - medics earn money for healing, for example. Between rounds, you use the cash you earn to buy new equipment, Counterstrike-style, or share that cash with teammates who need it more. Each perk (class) is designed to operate in some way unique from the others, and they complement each other extremely well, with some perks being better against certain enemies, and a variety of roles being essential for success.

What I love is that the balance in these games is very carefully tuned for them to be survivable, but only if you work together. It's not about getting the most kills, it's not about calling other people noobs; it's about survival and survival only, and liabilities cannot be tolerated.

If you hoard cash, the players will kick you. If you solo for most kills, the players will kick you. If you throw abuse at the medic, if you refuse to switch out to a higher perk level on high difficulty servers - if you act like an ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•, the players will kick you. The game absolutely requires teamwork to be survivable in most cases, so if you're not interested in working as a member of a team, don't bother buying the game.

Edity edit time!

Some people were concerned that the community doesn't like new players. That's not what I'm trying to say here. I should clarify: Killing Floor has difficulty ratings on its servers, and you'll be helped out on the lower difficulties, taught how to take enemies down, etc. I've put in time on beginner servers myself, doling out cash, pointing out hold points, protecting people from getting ganked.

It's when you graduate to higher difficulties you'll be expected to know your ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•. For those people saying Oh

Edity edit ends.

And how does Killing Floor 2 hold up? It is everything I wanted it to be as a KF1 veteran. It takes the same formula - co-operate or die - and adds all the polish that the original was arguably missing. Animations are fantastic

reviewText:
Early Access Review

-Keep in mind, this game being in early access means this could all do a 180 with a few bad updates and developer abandonment. I think that is highly unlikely with Tripwire, but its possible-

As of right now, Killing Floor 2 is in a very polished, but still very early state in early access. There is only one mode, 4 maps, one boss and a hand full of characters. However, if your looking for a zed shooter that feels so good, look no further than Killing Floor 2.

The game isn't even close to complete and already I feel it has some of the best gunplay out there. Every gun I've shot with feels amazing, shotguns feel heavy and strong, assault rifles feel fast and shred through weaker enemies, and so on. Of the weapons I've played with, they all feel amazing and not samey at all.

The game already has several enemy types that do a variety of things. I think I counted about 9 different types of zeds so far. That number might be off, but its around there. It has a lot of variety, is the meat of what I'm saying.

When president of game development company that wants to offer you hell-on-earth killing fest with lots of guns and knee-deep levels of gore also wears Impending Doom t-shirt in his interviews, you can expect some really serious stuff.

Tripwire is gradually growing to be my favorite shooter developers, and that's why:

I was one of those guys who got tired of first Killing Floor really fast, but even then i remember how well done weapons were in this game. Then Red Orchestra 2 arrived and i swear to god i was ready to marry this mosin rifle. Then, there is Killing Floor 2. In ungodly early access. By the same studio that couldn't make RO2 work for half a year since it's release (With satanic Punkbuster i swear to god i will find the ones that made this monstrousity and i will slap them in the face with overused condom for making mandatory useless software that was conflicting with two of my motherboards in a row).
And i can't say a single bad thing about KF2, nothing. There's nothing to nitpick. It just works. And offers so much fun for a modern game it's unbelievable EVEN with only 3 maps and four classes available so far.

While being modern shooter without archaic mechanics, it still offers you this old forgotten feeling when you're alone against horde of infernal ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•s with ten ammo up your mag and a rusty knife. Same feeling that you have in Doom when you dodge Arch's flames hiding behind fences and try to find any medkit or ammo ahead. Same feeling when you walk through the map and it looks like actual location instead of bunch of rooms. And feeling when you shoot your gun and feel the recoil. You only get this when developers really love their work.

Attention to detail in design of characters, maps and weapons is high enough to make online shooting gallery atmospheric. You reload a gun with bullets left in the mag - character puts this mag into his pocket. You blast off zombie's head while it's still crawling from the manhole - it will keep crawling blindly a bit before dying. Fat puking mister dude, while being decapitated, can still puke. Flamethrower zombie dude sets little ones blocking you behind on fire, effectively putting them into panic and killing them, so you can escape to get killed elsewhere. Invisible infidel women chant some kind of don't leave me..." stuff

KF2 feels a bit like a shadow of what KF1 is.

One of the most popular things in KF1 was to find a place to solidly hold up for a while, be it a long hallway or a room with one or two doors to watch. Even with the camping technique it was still very easy to get overwhelmed. KF2 is not quite teh same. There are usually 2 large open areas on each map which everyone congregates in, and then everyone runs around in circles trying to outkill everyone else. Pretty standard stuff to expect, I suppose. reviewText:
Early Access Review

I'd like to preface this 'review' with I love this game. But I can't, in good conscience let this slide. TWI has lost sight of their goal. They have their sights on sources of income. I am mostly fine with their cosmetic microtransactions (the prices could be tweaked a bit, and the different qualities such as battle scarred, field tested, mint, could be done away with), but they no longer have the original spirit as when they started. Whether this is because they are running out of money or any other reason is speculation at this point, but they are handling it completely wrong. I'd like to go over the primary reasons for my rant: things that they have promised and have done.

Censorship in the discussion board? Not cool, and completely undermines the United State's constitutional rights. Why are they doing this? well there could be various reasons: to promote their game in a more favorable light, or maybe since they have heard the criticism long enough they have built up tolerance for it and no longer deem them important. Maybe they hired some new guy who is going ham as a moderator. Regardless of what their intent is, censorship is not the answer. As people, we need positive and negative feedback to challenge ourselves and improve. Because of this, the only way to let others know about the issues in the game is to read reviews such as this one or find it elsewhere.

Attention to detail? Maybe, but I still see some slop in areas. I thought you guys had gun nuts on the dev team? The 9mm casings flying out of the Desert Eagle; double action trigger of a Beretta that is cocked is in the double action position instead of being in the single action position; hitting reload to mess with your scar or ak's ejection port and it stays closed.

Early Access done right? Again, maybe. When the game first launched, there were only 4 perks. Even then, switching between them caused some perks to carry over. Parry was pretty broken and inconsistent as well. Every update since then has had various bugs:
-Incinerate and Detonate? RPG and other shots do not go where you aim if you turn too fast and fire (I believe this is still an issue).
-Sharpshooter weapons release for feedback with a Prison map? Map crashes with the crossbow when picking up bolts.
-PVP? PVP had human players invulnerable to big zeds when a melee weapon was out. These just go to show how much testing they do before releasing these quality updates. Hell, we didn't even ask for PVP. It's a nice afterthought, but development time should have been spent on the core game. Afterall, we the consumers, and TWI wanted to retain that core gameplay loop" that made the original so fun and successful.

They have stopped pushing originally planned content and are now focusing on other areas: PVP and Microtransactions when their main game is not even completed yet.
Now you may be wondering

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Killing Floor 2Developer: Tripwire Interactive
Publisher: Tripwire Interactive

Note: A key for this game was provided by the developer for the purpose of writing an unbiased informative review. No other compensation was given.

Introduction
==========
I'm going to be really honest. I own and have played the original Killing Floor for less than an hour. I don't know why, but I just couldn't get into it. It seemed alright, but something about it just turned me off. I'm not very good at shooters either, but every now and then I find one that is so much fun that I keep playing and eventually get to be a little decent at it. Killing Floor 2 is one such shooter. This is a game that I could immediately pick up and enjoy. Even better is that it's not a competitive shooter...it's a co-op shooter! Also of note is that it's currently in Early Access, and is probably the best Early Access title I've played to date.

Gameplay
==========
Killing Floor 2 takes place one month after the events in the first Killing Floor. Horzine Biotech's failed experiment has had some disastrous results, and it's up to you and your companions to go into Zed hot zones and clear them out! The game's matchmaking system nearly instantly matches you to a game, where other players can join in/drop out when they please. The game is played on a wide variety of maps in what are called waves, and in each wave zeds are coming from nearly EVERYWHERE to kill you. Each wave has a number of zeds, and as you clear these waves they get more numerous, more diverse, and harder to kill. Each kill earns players dosh (money) and experience points that apply to their chosen perk (class) depending on their actions. Gain enough points to level up. Every 5 levels the player gets to choose a skill to unlock for their chosen perks. These skills vary in nature, but are extremely useful.

A bit about the players and their avatar: characters are somewhat customizable. There are a little more than a dozen characters to play as, each with certain features and accessories you can choose to customize them. It also looks like you can unlock more things for them to wear and more weapons to use by completing challenges or owning certain other games on Steam (example - Chivalry: Medieval Warfare).  There are 6 perks to choose from: Commando, Berserker, Support, Field Medic, Demolitionist, and Firebug. Each one levels up by performing actions pertinent to that perk. For example Firebug gains experience by using incendiary weapons, while Field Medic gains experience by healing teammates. You can earn experience for your perks even if you are not currently playing as that perk.

One of the neat things you can do is use a welder to seal strategic doorways shut for a time to allow your teammates time to regroup or heal. I thought this was a really cool concept, but make sure you use it in truly advantageous locations and coordinate with your teammates, or else it can just be a waste of time. Another thing is Zed Time, which is when time slows to an absolute crawl for a few seconds, allowing players to make very precise shots or maneuvers. This is triggered by certain actions, such as perfectly timed headshots.

As you clear waves, you get the opportunity to spend your hard-earned dosh at Trader Pods to buy new weapons, ammo, body armor, and many other items. Weapons and ammo can also be found scattered about map. After a period of time (I think it's exactly 1 minute, maybe a tad more), the next wave begins. After the last wave, a boss will appear. Once the boss goes down, the game is won...and it just starts over on a new map, which players can vote on in their results screen. The results screen shows your high scores" and how much experience points you get from your actions

Killling floor is certainly a rising star, a diamond in the rough, a game that clearly has potential, as evident by the fact that the core game runs flawlessly for the most part, looks amazing and operates smoothly. But alas, due to the recent actions overtaken by the developer of the game, TWI, this potential is all but wasted.
First of all, ill elaborate a bit more on what makes Killing floor 2 a good game in principal. The graphical upgrade over its predecassor is clearly visible, and much welcomed. The new gore system, along with the persistent blood mechanic is also a nice and fitting addition to the game. Weapon handling is moreover, heavily improved, with loads of new animations, and weapon features. All of these make for a solid base, in which KF2 could build so much on, and become a truly amazing game.

As for the actions that completely undermine the current and future success of the game, they seemingly have no end, but ill try and sum them up.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Detailed review below the video.
https://youtu.be/18H0vWXShw4

Hard day at the office? School work bringing you down? Girl problems? Nobody understands you? Just having a rotten day? If you are like me sometimes you just want to forget about life‚Äôs problems and take out your aggressions with some mindless fun. On the surface, that‚Äôs what Killing Floor is all about. Head shot hordes and hordes of Zombies (Zeds) to survive the wave just to do it again. If you dig a bit deeper there is strategy to be found and tactics to be had but nothing your brain doesn‚Äôt have to think too hard about. Your biggest decision is picking out what weapon you want to use to impale some Zombies with.

If you have played the original Killing Floor you know exactly what to expect here. It‚Äôs the same formula with new maps, new weapons, and new Zeds.  As of the Early Access release there is nothing gameplay wise that sets it apart from the original. No jet packs, no vehicles, no air strikes, just good old fashioned Killing Floor. It is far more polished then the original, the graphics have greatly improved, and somehow TripWire made it even more fun. This is partially due to the amazing frames of motion in Zed time that has greatly improved over the original.

At its Early Access state you are getting a well-polished game. I have not had a single freeze or crash. I have only witnessed a few very minor graphical glitches and have had no issues joining servers. You are only getting three maps and one boss at its current state but Tripwire promises plenty of more content and we have no reason not to believe them based on their previous track record.

This is a definite buy in my book.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Review after Revenge of the ZED's update:
April 8, 2016

TL;DR: The current game is polished, exciting, and a lot of co-op fun.  It holds a lot of potential as a finished product but the development process is leaving a lot to be desired, thus all the negative reviews as the community is making their disappointment known.

It appears the community's cumulative morale is significantly lower than a few months ago.  Understandably so as TWI just spent over four months creating a PvP gamemode that does not appeal to the majority of their fanbase and the current lack of balance makes it appear more as a tack-on gimmick.  Although I somewhat understand TWI's viewpoint of attempting to expand the playerbase, postponing the long-awaited sharpshooter perk which many have been waiting for since early access release almost a year ago is not doing any favors for the community.

The added Game Conductor could use some tweaking, but it adds a very nice dynamic to the games that was not previously present.  It certainly makes lower difficulties more enjoyable to play casually but playing on higher difficulties for the challenge while having the game punish players for doing well is absurd.

As many other reviews states, as the price will not change between early access and full release (not regarding currency fluxuations or steam sales) either wait for a finished build (most likely around early 2017... serious estimate) or purchase now and deal with the bugs that comes with early access games and development.

==============================================================

I did not write a review for the Return of the Patriarch patch back in December 2015, so I think I'll put my few cents here for now.  That content update not only had the Patriarch and the well-received gunslinger perk, but it included microtransactions and opened an entire can of worms for the community to digest.  Very many were unhappy for essentially the following reasons:

1. The game is not even close to getting out of Early Access and TWI had the audacity to implement this system as if their game is complete.

2. The devs diverted time and effort to add this feature which prolongs the wait before the game's release.  Do note that 95% of the content are from community submissions and a seperate team worked on this implementation.

3. The community has never asked for a microtransactions process nor was it mentioned at all in the early access statement although it is clear with the implementation of the curating workshop near the beginning of early access that it was their plan from the very start.

Long story short, many are not happy, but the system is still present.

Perhaps the biggest positive about the microtransactions system is that currently it is cosmetic only and is not mandatory for enjoyment of the game.  I feel a factor for the huge resistance from the community was due to the Payday 2 fiasco with their poor implementation of microtransactions mere weeks before and also TWI announced this news to the community that were waiting months for an update and heard what they never wanted to hear.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I do not recommend buying this game right now. Sadly, Killing Floor 2 has been a complete let down from what I expected. Killing Floor 1 has combos/strategies which after a lot of practice in test maps, allowed you to become a master in certain perks and weapons to kill Scrakes and Fleshpounds. In Killing Floor 2 you just need to aim and shoot (unless you are a Berserker or a firebug, which don't even require aiming). I used to have some hope for these to be implemented, since they seemed to be most important feature of KF. But now after seeing how many other features that deviate from the core of Killing Floor have already made it into the game, it's clear combos are not part of TWI's plans for this game.

The core mechanics that allow for a higher skill ceiling, a deeper understanding of the AI behavior, and a precise/advanced application of the available perks and weapons, are just not present. This is what made the game fun for me during hundreds of hours in KF1, and this is why I am now bored of playing KF2.

It is very disappointing that there is no M32. Demo is my favorite KF1 perk, but it is a true disgrace in KF2 with how underpowered its tier 1 and 2 weapons are, how boring the RPG is, and the uselessness of the C4. Don't even get me started on the perk skills which always have an obvious choice and seem to have been designed by someone who hated being handed that task (to be honest, all the perks' skills give off this vibe; very few of them are actually interesting and useful).

I also loved to do combos on FPs and Scrakes as Support Specialist in KF1 but it is severely underpowered in KF2 as well; little ammo, a weak hunting shotgun, and no nade stacking makes this perk a sad representation of what is once was. Meanwhile, noobish perks like Berserker and Firebug that just require spamming mouse 1, can deal with these easily.

It is also insulting that the developer was so quick to push Microtransactions onto the players' faces, trying to cash in as much as possible on the very audience that once trusted them to develop the potentially great sequel to a game that they love. This to me is utter disrespect, because the game is in Early Access, sharpshooter is not even out (MTs were released even before gunslinger came out), the current perks are not properly balanced, the AI mechanics are super basic, and there are still annoying bugs that need to be fixed. But the cash machine had to be released first.

On top of that, the developer decided that a Player vs. Player game mode was also more important than working on the Sharpshooter perk which EVERYONE loves and were expecting. I don't know of ANYONE who wanted a PvP mode in KF. I have ZERO interest in PvP in Killing Floor. Four months were wasted working on this ridiculously boring and subpar PvP experience.

Lastly KF2 has excessive head bobbing. So much that I get dizzy after playing for a while. the screen shakes too much while running, shooting, and reloading. It's incredibly annoying and makes the game look very gimmicky. KF1 successfully manages to display feedback effortlessly and without screen shaking. In fact, many weapons feel even more powerful in KF1 than in KF2 (Hunting Shotgun, LAR, 9MM, Handcannons, Trenchgun).

How is such a regression Possible?

So probably first of all I should say I really enjoyed the original. So much that I actually got all 285 achievements in it, hence you might assume I was quite excited when they announced the sequel. The game is everything the original was with a handful of enhacements to the gameplay itself and several new features like character customization to stand out from another person who might be using the same character.

Core gameplay remains the same, so fans of the original will get what they expected with an added challenge as the difficulty has been ramped up thanks to the new AI and map design. Now this game changes everything about this cheap standard as in Killing Floor 2 with higher difficulty, also changes the bahaviour of the AI and the enemies get entirely new attack sets that you never see them using on let's say Normal" difficulty. Early Access Review

I don't recommend it in its Early Access stage.

The updates are painfully slow, promises have been broken and the game is obviously having an identity crisis, in terms of its player base and what it essentially wants to become at a later date.

I really like vanilla KF2 and haven't touched PVP since it was added to the game. It's clearly just more pressure for TWI and they're steering away from refining their core gameplay. i'm personally all about the PVE gameplay as this is what Killing Floor is all about. If PVP was added after early access, that would have been better; players bought this game since the start for its PVE aspects, not PVP. Just because a game is in Early Access doesn't mean that features need to be added to make use of the community. That is...if there is anyone listening to the community. TWI could easily use discussion boards and forums outside EA for the development of more features...but no.

I've played with different perks through KF2's development but due to how slow the game's been updating i've just been using Commando and have since been playing the game much less. In the end, I just uninstalled the game and have told myself to wait unti the game exits Early Access.

I would advise you to wait as well.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

In principle this game is good. It continuates the system of Killing Floor 1 with far better graphics, smoother gameplay, more gore, more different zeds, etc. The gunplay feels as good as ever. Dismembering zeds is very satisfying and in slomo it's even better. There are more perks, there is a better progression system, and that's all very good.

But here is the big 'but', 'however' and 'yet'. There are fewer guns for each perk (only 4 each instead of 5-10 for each perk) which doesn't allow for much diverse gameplay. And, despite all their promises, the game is still in early access and they appear to spend time on other projects (like a mobile version or a playstation version) instead of finishing the game first.
Yes, there are more perks available now than at the start of the Early Access but even after almost a year, the game is still not finished (even though they said they needed only 6 months). We are still waiting for at least 4 perks and updates are very sparse.

In its current state and because of broken promises, I can't rate this game very high. There is promise, but they screwed over their fanbase and the players who had faith in them, myself included. They should stop mucking about and finish this game already. It's a shame they proved to be such a big disappointment, because there was such potential.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

ABOUT MICROTRANSACTIONS: As far as they don't affect weapons or maps, I don't care the store that is selling cosmetics. I'm not going to review negatively a game that I really enjoy because of MT. As far as I know, as the number of enemies is tied to the number of players, any inactive person will be kicked quickly.

Killing Floor 2 is a co-op game (6 players max) you can play in Solo. You can be a medic (healing), a commando (rifle) , a support (shotgun), a berserker (melee), a firebug (fire weapons), a gunslinger (pistols) or a demo (explosive). Your goal is to survive 4, 7 or 10 waves of enemies until you meet the new boss, Hans Volter, more vicious than the Patriach in KF or the Patriarch himself, revamped and more wanting to be at close contact. Your perks can be leveled up, improving their specific skills. Every 5 levels, you can choose between two skills and activate it (but you can change later, you're not stuck with it for the rest of the game).

I can't really speak for a lot of classes. For me, the commando and the support didn't really changed, like the firebug. Berserker felt a lot harder and medic.... I'm a medic first in that game. And leveling the medic was kinda hard before. I mean, the only way to do it was to heal. But now, the medic weapons can help! And these are more efficient than in KF. At least, I feel like I can do more damage (but still less than a good AA-12 as support) and heal and leveling up to be better! For the demo, I feel like it's missing some more explosive (I'm missing my pipe bombs or the M-32 launcher). The gunslinger is perhaps only wielding pistols but the 500 Magnum is so powerful compared to KF that I've been feeling good with that class.

Anyway, some new weapons are really good in their looks: the medic weapons are in a flashy blue, or the ultimate weapon for firebug is coming from a sci-fi movie. The guns for the gunslinger are coming from the Far West.

For the maps, they're varied: Horzine labs, Paris, an outpost in the mountains, a manor (well, belonging to the boss), catacombs in Rome, a harbor in Denmark... True, playing these maps is making you an expert on them at the end. But given the enemies (they didn't changed, they just added a new type of zed and they changed the Fleshpound and Scrake behiavor), you'll need to know every escape road. Black Forest is itself a new experience: you begin with a sunny weather before going progressively to a foggy and nightly ambiance.

If several characters are already present (with a female one included), the new feature is that you can customize them: hair color, clothes, accessories.... They're also from different cultures, which is also nice. You'll find Mr. Foster and DJ Scully as veterans from the first opus.

Graphically, it's beautiful. I can't really say that I don't enjoy the snow or Paris by night or even the extravagant manor. But the fact that you can move chairs, tables, destroy lamps and diving into the dark suddenly (that's Catacombs mainly). And for the sountrack, while some tracks are just a remix of the original KF, others are new and it's really fitting with the atmosphere.

I'm not sure if I did justice to KF2 with that review. But it's better than KF if you love being a medic. At least, hitting a character with the syringue will always result in a heal and not one time on two like in KF!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Changing from a Yes to a No.

If you're a Killing Floor 1 veteran or anyone coming from Killing Floor 1 to 2 then this game will be a huge disappointment for you. Killing Floor 2 doesn't have any of the core features nor the depth that made Killing Floor 1 a great game. For example, every perk in Killing Floor 1 could hold it's own no matter the threat. Soloing wasn't a problem, the game had combos, the zeds were huge threats but could be tamed and killed very quickly if you knew what you were doing. You had no room for error unless you got SUPER lucky. If anyone fails to kill a large zed then that could cost you the whole game. As for Killing Floor 2 all that is thrown out the window. Perks are now very easy to use and most your problems are solved by simply running away (Every perk can outrun a Scrake in Killing Floor 2, mistakes don't matter if you're faster than everything chasing you. In the first game the Scrake was the fastest zed in the game). Also, there isn't a way for a player to show off their skill in Killing Floor 2 since most perks are just trash cleaners, some better than others, most can't even solo the large zeds in a 6 player Hell on Earth game. While Killing Floor 1 gave you tools to take out the large zeds with a wide variety of weapons and express your skill, Killing Floor 2 removes all that completely for the sake of having you go from Tier1Weapon > Tier 2> Tier 3 > etc. It's basically a modern shooter with zeds, perks, and guns from the previous game stamped into a new engine.



*AS A COMPLETELY NEW PLAYER*

Yes, you'll love Killing Floor 2. It plays very modern and it's an enjoyable casual experience if you just want to relax with friends and mess around. The game is in early acess so most of the things i'm about to list are in relation to that. Updates are currently really slow, all the perks from Killing Floor 1 are in the game, and new perks get added like every 4 months. Balancing is a huge issue in this game, there is a severe lack of ammo (IN A ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•ING SHOOTING GAME) around the maps, not to mention the perks that really need ammo have really low magazine sizes. Most games just consist of people using the useful perks because some perks are just horrible for what they were designed to do. The game doesn't have many weapons so you'll pretty much know every weapon after playing a few games. The soundtrack is great, the visuals are great, the community is great (usually very nice people even the good players).


EDIT- Forgot to mention a few other things. A broken mechanic introduced into the game a WHILE ago. Depending on how many zeds remain on the map (5 or less) scrakes and fleshpounds will permanently rage and never stop running at you. While you can outrun scrakes, you can't outrun fleshpounds. It's basically GG if you have a remaining fleshpound because it will always catch up to you and the game gives you no ammo. On top of that the other zeds teleport A LOT and so blatantly ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•ing obvious, like in your face obvious, which makes the gameplay just not fun and even more boring. The matchmaking system is (still) broken. New players not using the server browser will join any game no matter the difficulty just so it can place them in a game. This causes a lot of toxic behavior in the community because new players don't understand the difficulties and the veteran players don't like seeing low level players in the really tough difficulties. Vote to kick is also abused, I mean it's not surprising but also very annoying.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nTripwire ruined KF2 with their own incompetence.  They don't seem to understand what made KF1 so great and have made a game" that does not feel like KF1 and does not feel fun in general.  Anyone who has played KF1 for a great length will have developed an equilibrium
date:
a certain baseline of expectation from gameplay.  Things that you might expect to do or see in KF2 if you're used to KF1 would be understandable but let's just run through a brief list of things that Tripwire decided to change and have left me scratching my head as to why they chose to do so.

Sirens scream no longer pull you towards them or really obscure your vision.

Clot variants when grabbing you force you to look at them... Why? Who knows.

Stunning was more or less removed and replaced with a cluster‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• of crowd control effects that are on wacky cooldowns and suffer from unreliable usefulness.  Stumbles
recommended: and knockdowns and knockbacks sound good
hoursPlayed:
but in practice a large number of skills and weapons can trigger these effects and there's no way of knowing if the random guy on your team is going to waste a stumble on a zed before the fight even starts because he accidently shot it in the leg with his medi gun.

Sprinting was added but melee move speed was removed for everyone except zerker.

Meleeing was added to every weapon.  This sounds good on paper because meleeing with weapons is a decent way to cause a stumble on a zed.... except that everyone else on your team can do exactly the same thing which means that when you really need to stumble that scrake who's destroying your face with a chainsaw it's already on cooldown!  So you waste time meleeing the zed for barely any damage instead of shooting it.

Medic gun darts can home in on wounded targets.  Because challenging the medics aim skill instead of just making them dart dispensers is too hard?

Welding doors was removed from the game
voteText: well not really but it's the most ruined mechanic in a game I've ever seen.  Doors don't respawn and that's fine

but WHY DO DOORS HAVE A FINITE AMOUNT OF HEALTH?  Nobody wastes time welding doors because there's no telling when they're going to break! What are you thinking Tripwire?

You spawn with a tier 1 weapon now for every perk at every level.  This fosters a sense of self reliance among new players instead of gently persuading the players to work together like kf1 where you just spawned with a knife and 9mm unless you were level 5 or higher.  This also dilutes the experience of upgrading your arsenal and progressing through the weapon ranks.

Medics get far more xp for killing than healing.

ZED DIRECT ATTACKS HOME IN ON YOU.  Let that sink in.  If it isn't a whirlwind from a scrake or a few other things like the husk shooting at you the zed will literally turn in mid air and his meat blender or claw will connect with you as you dodge past him.  I imagine there are some scenarios where they won't hit you but in KF2 the zeds will hit you while you're dodging about as often as the zeds in kf1 would miss you if you were dodging.

Zed's have sprinting animations and while it looks cool it makes them a nightmare to shoot in the head especially when coupling in the strange fact that...

Zed's no longer seem to focus on the closest player.  Back in KF1 if you had a team set up in an area and a zed walks around the corner he would almost invariably target the closest player to him. reviewText:
Early Access Review

Killing Floor 2 was a game I had high hopes for. I joined in on KF1 only a few years ago, but it quickly became one of my favorite games, so of course I hopped right on the KF2 hype train. I didn't expect a perfect game upon release of early access, but I was at least confident that it would turn out all right. Boy was I wrong. I can excuse the slow progress for new content; they're a relatively small company. But there's a lot of things that they did that really don't make sense. They claimed they wanted to balance the game over time, yet they had no method of making small balance patches until a month or two ago, resulting in often terrible balance between major (quarterly) updates. They added a pvp mode that nobody wanted. Sure, they say the game mode development team made it, but what does having two modes imply? It implies they either need to balance guns with consideration for both modes, or create separate balance changes between modes. Both solutions result in requiring more work. Microtransactions wouldn't be so bad if they weren't pure randomness with crates and keys. As it is right now, your only options for getting that one accessory you want are either to spend lots of dosh hoping for what you want, or to buy the item from other players for more money than its probably worth. It doesn't help that in recent months, Tripwire has only added fuel to the fire. A majority of their recent patches have given the impression that they are prioritizing pvp, and forum moderators are becoming trigger happy with the bans for anyone critical of their game. I still get the impression that Tripwire intends to finish this game, and that slow development (at least recently) is partially due to the fact that they lost developers and are having a hard time replacing them. However, a long series of bad decisions and lack of communication has resulted in a snowball of (understandable) negativity in parts of the community. Now, they have resorted to hiding this negativity as much as possible, both on the steam discussion pages and on their own forums. There's so much more I'd like to list but for the sake of brevity, I hope anyone who reads this has already gotten the point.

Anyway, sorry for the long tangent. Back to the actual quality of the game itself: the visuals are great and everything looks amazing compared to killing floor 1.  Game balance is poor, but hopefully that gets fixed eventually. For me, KF2 lacks the replayability of KF1, in its current state. I don't know exactly why, so don't ask. Basically what you should take from this is that if you liked KF1, it doesn't mean you'll like KF2. And now for the bottom line: Is KF2 fun? It's fun when playing with friends (whether they're real life friends or ones you made over the net). But when those friends give up on the game and uninstall because they've lost faith in the developers, it stops being fun. In other words, don't get this game if you want to join public groups with randoms.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game might be worth the $30. I got a few hundred hours out of it when it was fun trying to beat HoE with teamwork, and the balance of the perks was decent.

But I was expecting to get more than 1k hours out of this game, like I did from Killing Floor 1. Killing Floor 2 doesn't have any interesting combos to kill big zeds, and perks like firebug and berserker can get away with killing them without even aiming.

The developer has been gradually messing up the balance of the game and doesn't listen to feedback, which is the exact opposite of what they promised to do during Early Access.

Now the pinnacle of Tripwire Interactive's middle finger to its playerbase is spending 4 months working on a PvP mode which very few people asked for, instead of working on the much awaited sharpshooter perk and balancing the existing perks. I personally have absolutely no interest in PvP in Killing Floor.

I expected a challenging game to follow up KF1's greatness, with similar techniques to kill zeds with flinches, mini-flinches, and finely-timed combos; but KF2 is nothing of that. The skill ceiling is pretty low, and it will get boring fast.

Killing Floor 2 is a dumbed down version of KF1 to appeal to the soon-to-come console playerbase, and keep the braindead item collectionists content through its Microtransactions platform.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Genre - Co-op wave based FPS

I enjoyed the first killing floor in small doses, mainly due to the active co-op element, and also the British influence. I decided to get this after watching gameplay videos, and watching the short film that got me in the mood.

The characters you can play have their own voices and can be customised more now. You can also chose one of four classes for added perks. This allows you to add your own influence on any game. These classes can be levelled up as you play each game.

After several waves of enemy types, which are the same as in the original game, I think this was a case of if it ain't broke don't fix it. You get to fight the boss. This is the hardest part of the game and can also be the most frustrating, There is only one boss type at the moment, although I hope they will add more, with different tactics needed to beat them. The current one will spam various gas and explosives and will charge you to drain your life force. You will need to work as a team to defeat him.

There are currently three levels and they all look great and have unique designs. The weapons are varied enough, with the new Medic weapons adding some class.

The servers are quite active already so you won't have any trouble finding a game.

If you want a co-op game where you shoot stuff with new friends but don't want to be bothered with side missions and a story then this is the game for you.

I bought this awhile ago thinking it would get updated frequently. they added a few guns since then but overall the updates are almost non-existent and the game feels very bare and repetitive.

Guns are few for each class and there really isn't much player choice on how you want to play if you want to play effectively.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Killing Floor 2 is the long awaited new part of the shooter  Killing Floor " which was coming out in 2009. Both parts were made by Tripwire Interactive. Killing Floor is basicly a survival 6 man co-op shooter where the task is to survive waves of zeds ( zeds are the monsters). Killing Floor 2 comes with the same idea but much more faster and fresher. The zeds got smarter and they spawn from all directions and if you run away you can be surprised by some. Also the environment takes a big part in KF2. When you throw grenades for example in a room full of lights than  the lights will go off and the room will get completely dark.

KF2 comes also with a really nice graphic. The game was developed with the unreal engine 3. The maps are full of blood and corpses and there are coming more as well during your game. Heads and arms are flying when you shoot them. Its much more brutal than Killing Floor 1.

In my opinion you cant do anything wrong with this part and you should buy it if you are a fan of co-op survival shooters.

Graphics: 9/10
Gameplay: 10/10
Teamplay: 9/10
Maps: 10/10

This game is just outstanding.

9.5/10 For what are you waiting for ? Go and kill some zeds."

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I used to love this game. I was a huge fan of the original Killing Floor and I've always supported Tripwire in their endeavors in making KF2. However, I have to write this review with deep disapointment for Tripwire.

To start off, Killing Floor 2 at the core as a game works and is fun.  It's good traditional horde based combat with stellar animations, visuals, and gunplay. That fun is very limited though, as this game has been in EA for nearly a whole year and filled with nothing but broken promises.

Content is still missing and there are numerous issues/bugs that have yet to be patched: the release of SWAT/Martial Artist or any information, Support Specialist is severly underpowered and is outclassed by Gunslinger, Demolition has been nerfed to the ground even though you had to get Level 25 to make him useful in the past, the skill trees lack any variety/depth and do not make you feel like you're customizing your class to play the way you want to play, maps are filled with exploits making them incredibly easy to beat even on the highest difficulty, functionality of the game has drastically dropped and now the game  is filled with hitches. With many more numerous issues that are too lengthy to add to this review.

They also introduced a cash shop in the game to a title which was already lacking so little content from the get go. Now while I do respect all the wonderful artist who sent their items in and have been approved, I cannot support them in this buisness practice as it detracts from the goal of the original games content and a finalized product. It's hard to support this game and its artist when updates only come around every 4-5 months which bring minor content that can be finished in no time. How can you expect one to buy skins/cosmetics to keep me entertained if I've completed nearly 90% of the content? There is hardly anything to go back to.

The addition of a VS mode has not helped in anyway in making this game fun for the community. It's a tacked on gamemode which very little balance surrounding it. Because of this, balance issues will be distributed towards fixing this game mode that lacks any signifigance outside of being just a tacked on cliche'. Ultimately it's a gamemode nobody asked for.

Last but not least, broken promises. The devs, while friendly, have broken many promises that the community was told they would receieve. One of them in particular was making crawlers (a spider-like enemy) crawl on surfaces within the game. When asked when they would receive it, TW's response was It's too hard
date: we cannot do it." .\n\nI defended this game for a long time; but today I've had enough. It pains me to say this but you should not purchase this game anytime soon until the full intial release from early access. It's a 30 dollar game with potential that is ultimately stopped by a development crew who doesn't care enough to release things in a timely or well designed/balanced manner. I wish all purchasers good luck as we wait for another 4-5 months for the next update and all potential purchasers to wait for a very big sale or a free weekend."

reviewText:
Early Access Review

First of all I'd like to say that at the time of reviewing this game it is in a really early build and will be subject to changes as the game gets developed. For now this review will focus on what is in the game at this current time.

A quick list of Pros and Cons: Pros:
Good Graphics compared to the first game.
Great community of players.
Extremely addictive!
A decent amount of classes to choose from, each with different perks and 25 levels.
Very well optimized.
Extremely gory and fun with friends.
Smart working AI
Decent amount of weapons currently in the game.
Currently 4 highly detailed maps. (2 smaller maps and 2 larger maps.)
It's just a great game to throw time into.

Cons:
Some community members can be uncooperative which can ruin the game.
The last boss can shoot and damage you through walls at times.
The Scrake AI can be tricked into spinning around and not attack you.
To be fair, there are not many cons to this game.. It's such a good laugh even when you are playing by yourself and all the cons that are there are to be expected for an early access game.

This brings me to the big question of if the game is worth the money Tripwire are charging for it?

I believe that this game is worth every bit of what they are charging for it, you get a stable game with extremely addictive gameplay and a development team that you can rely on to update the game quickly. I would rate this game but it is in early access and giving it a numbered rating at this stage would be silly, just buy the game and play it already.

I'm not a friend of Early Access Games or how the community likes to call them E.A." titles.

Killing Floor as a series sits on top of a very simple premise for a video game: There are a number of monsters, you kill them, you get better gear at a checkpoint, you fight a bigger number of monsters next round and you repeat this until you get to the biggest of them. The first title in this franchise executed its basic premise using an almost perfect formula, mixing player skill as well as knowledge to provide a thrilling experience on all levels of play for something that would otherwise become a monotonous and repetitive task.

Sadly, Killing Floor 2 distanced itself from that formula, applied most of its budget in the art department, kept bad things about the first game, worsened others, and, instead of listening to feedback from people who actually invested their time to analyze the title, developers began to build it around its errors that catered to new players, mostly to keep their own egos intact:

Aiming for a quicker and modernized experience, the game's pacing was increased; yet, somehow, the killing" aspect was made slower:

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Very good teamwork shooting zombie's game.
It's fast, it's hectic and the classes you can choose from are great.
The whole team benefits when you upgrade your different characters.

If you get bored of the shooting (can't imagine but say if that's so) you can choose to become a Beserker. They are an important part of a team and they are there to get face to face with the big zombies to give them some @ss kicking. Berserkers are all about timing while the rest of the team clears out the rest of the zombies or go about there specialisation. There's a medic, support, commando, fire and demolition specialist. Each character has their own set of specialist weapons. You can be all of them and upgrade each and one of them by playing a lot.

At the start of each game you can see who's in the team and wich character they are playing and at what level. You get a special upgrade every 5 levels and for each character there are 25 levels. You can change your character before you start each game so each person can pick the character to complement the team. It's a lot of fun and if you like shooting, teamwork and killing zombies you're in the right place.

Oh! The communatie is fine by the way. I heard some bad things about it, but in my more than 50 hours of gameplay I only met nice people. So you know.

Early Access Review

Another disappointing Early Access release that rakes in money with hype and the promise of being better and more fun than its predecessor whilst quietly hiding its many flaws with bland promises.

The updates are slow and the game's barely any different from when it got released. There's plenty of issues that should be fixed or changed such as the fact that enemies at the end of the round are permanently enraged and the issue that enemies like to teleport around, especially in front of you in corridors so you get locked into a death trap. The amount of guns at the moment is just sad, with only one obvious upgrade to the gun you start with the variety in the game isn't good. Classes, or perks" as they're called in Killing Floor
date:
are unbalanced and having a "balanced" team can often be worse than spamming a single overpowered perk. Not to mention the game is downright repetitive as hell right now with the lack of content.

With so much work still left to do and almost a year into development I'm only left wondering how they have the nerve to  put in microtransactions. With a game as hyped as this the development won't go any faster with additional cosmetics nor won't you see any of that money back in upcoming updates.

My suggestion? Get Killing Floor 1 first and wait how the development goes with Killing Floor 2."

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game looks stunning and plays well compared to its predecessor.

When, of course, it is functioning.
Never before have I played a game that crashes this much, let alone the other problems It has given me just for trying to play it. The PhysX variant (FleX, an extremely advanced PhysX extension) is brilliant when it works, but only makes the game even more crashy than it already was. (EDIT: It works much better after the last patches and such. Still needs some optimization.)

Probably the biggest note I can make is the serious lack of content. This game is pretty barebones, and a lot of the perks lack the power and utility that the perks in the original had, giving every enemy an uncomfortably spongey feel even if you are landing the headshots... Even with the improved gunplay, this feels awful.

This game plays and feels like a ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• free to play game. IT EVEN HAS MICROTRANSACTIONS. IN EARLY ACCESS. THAT IS RIGHT, MICROTRANSACTIONS IN EARLY ACCESS. Not only do we basically have day 1 DLC, we have  MICROTRANSACTIONS. I could forgive the rest of this game's misses and issues were it not for the fact that this dev team has invested time in creating a system of microtransactions rather than creating content for their unfinished, poorly functioning game. This is disgusting, and completely disgraceful.

Finally, a TL;DR list of things.
-Unimpressive, bullet spongey zeds with no real clever ways to kill them outside of cheese glitches that are numerous. This does not mean they are hard, what it does mean is that they are just as boring as they were in the last game.
-The game is crash-tastic. If you plan on taking advantage of Nvidia FleX, the physX extension they use, don't. It will make the crashes worse.
-Some serious optimization issues, probably related to the crashing.
-A lot of the classes just plain suck, even for their niches.
-10/10 would uninstall again.

DO NOT BUY THIS GAME. PLAIN AND SIMPLE. IT IS NOT READY FOR A PUBLIC AUDIENCE, AND AT THIS RATE, NEVER WILL BE.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

The developers have faithfully recreated much of the original KF. Better animation, graphics, and‚Ä¶.er‚Ä¶.. well....still the same monsters....pretty much same guns....maps look the same...pretty much‚Ä¶..well‚Ä¶.pretty much the same game! In fact the new one even  looks out of date! Just not so much as KF1.

If you don't know KF then it's a simple plot. Well, actually, there is no plot. You have a gun, there are lots of bad things that need shooting. Everything you shoot you earn money to buy more ammo to shoot more things. It's as simple as that. Simple, but amazingly good fun. And you'd better like gory, ooky stuff becuase there is literally dumper truck loads of it in this game.

So we have an updated version of the original game, which is still very much the same game. It's a really promising start because they haven't completely messed it up, but at the moment there isn't really enough new stuff in there for me to fully recommend it. If I were you, I would wait a little while to see how the game develops. Provided they add lots of interesting stuff then it's going to be a classic, but if they are too afraid to introduce some nice new stuff then...well....it will all come to nothing.

Recommended? I will say yes becuase it is a promising start, but you might like to hang on a bit longer to see how it goes.

That is basically the story of this games product life-cycle for the time being. The gameplay is great, and it's very polished for an early-access game. But the sheer lack of content is killing... well, Killing Floor.

You'll wait a couple of months for an update, only find out that they fixed some minor bugs that you've never experienced, or made minor balance changes, it is beyond ridiculous. What makes the situation worse is that the implementation of microtransactions has not helped the situation, the cosmetic items available through the marketplace add nothing to the gamplay at all.
When new content is actually added to the game, it's fantastic. But given that we get so little and over such ludicrous periods of time; I've found myself playing the updated content to death, getting bored of it(because there isn't a great deal) and then repeating with the next update.

Now, to be perfectly clear and lacking of bias; this complaint is my only MAJOR reason to recommend against buying the game. Since I bought the game, some time last year, there have been three major content updates(using the word 'major' very loosely here).
- the first added one new map
- the second two maps, and two perks
- the third, two maps, one perk and a new boss

As the game so stands, we have eight official maps, seven perks/classes, and two bosses - each with a 50% chance of spawning at the last wave. The problem is that once you've familiarised yourself with the core content in the game now, the developers at TWI simply cannot keep up with the demand, and as a result additional features are being burned out faster than they can be produced. Which all in all, leaves me pretty bummed out.

I've played 70 hours, I'd say that its good for perhaps 20-40 in its current state. If you believe thats value for money, by all means purchase the game.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

To be honest, this game is really, really good. Really good. So I'm guessing you're wondering why I've given this a negative review. Well, let's start with what I like about this game.

Pros:
- Gunplay feels really good and solid for the most part. It feels like the guns really do have recoil on them, and if you can't control that, you're in for a bad day.
- Character lines are funny and entertaining, but not overused: they scream to move when something big comes, or you can taunt if you're feeling gutsy.
- The few TWI maps that have been released are amazing. Manor and Paris are easily my favorites. They look good, weather effects look damn good, everything looks damn good.
- The perks work well with on perk weapons and off perk weapons. That being said, it always helps to have on perk weapons. One of TWI's designs was to have more off perk weaponry used. But more on that later.
- The enemies (or ZED's) are really well done, their models are damn good and the way they attack is superb. Going up in dificulty enables the ZED's to have different attacks than normal, some of which can be fatal very quickly.
- The music is awesome (it's some nice heavy metal mixed in with some death metal; but more on music later).
- The difficulties do make the game more difficult instead of making everything a bullet sponge like in the original game.

Now that I've said what I like about this game... Sadly it's time to give the long list of things I don't like. And that's a long list indeed.

Con's:
- Once you get really good with a weapon it feels weak. Going up in levels in your perk tree makes the weapons more powerful damage wise, but it feels like I'm using a pea shooter instead of the Varmint Rifle. Very few guns retain their 'badassness' throughout the levels.
- Support class is easily the most OP class in the game. The standard shotgun can be used until wave 3/4, where you can buy an AA12 and just wreck with that. That's what I do on HoE (Hell on Earth). Even a new guy can easily last an entire game with just the starting shotgun and then buying the AA12. It's lack of spread is rediculous, and it's fire rate is easily faster than any machinegun. It can take out a Fleshpound in roughly 11-12 rounds. No other perk can kill off a Fleshpound that quickly. Even the final boss is a wimp with 2-3 AA12's blasting into him.
- The characters themselves feel a little clunky, and sprinting is almost like a waste of time (it does let you move a little faster though...) as bigger enemies, cloakers and crawlers can easily catch up to a sprinting player. Taunting does nothing to the ZED's and just makes you feel like an idiot when you do (I love taunting though, some funny lines right there) as it doesn't enrage ZED's nor does it make them target you. A potential use for taunting could be being used as a tank or for drawing cannon fodder.
- TWI take their sweet, sweet time with updates. And to be honest I haven't played this game since the mannor update because there isn't enough content. It feels like TWI are relying on the modding community to create maps to pass the time whilst they create a single new one. It's been 3-4 months since the last update. As such, there is an extreme lack of content that many people will get bored of very quickly (3-4 weapons per class, 4 classes so far, 2 more to be added in soon and like 4 maps in total). The community made maps are really good, but it's also nice to see a map made by TWI. TWI, I feel, need to realise that for EA to work, they need to be constantly releasing smaller sized updates, perhaps an update every month, instead of 1 massive one whenever they feel like (as stated earlier, it's been many months since the last update). I also beleive they need to start letting the community know rough dates (month of August, for example) for when updates are coming out. We are kept in the dark about a lot of things and whilst the community smashes the forums with posts about updates, nothing is done about them and no word from the developers themselves. (I know that they are against setting dates but a rough estimate for an update isn't too hard).
- Perk weapons are still used by their perks. If I'm support, I will rarely ever use a varmint rifle to pick off enemies at distance because it's easier and quicker to close the distance first. And besides, every perk can hit at distance if you're good enough. I would rather just sell off any found weapons that aren't used for my perk.
- ZED's can currently teleport and this is my biggest issue. If you run away from a ZED, they will teleport to the nearest spawn point to you and randomly appear. This means that you can be on Burning Paris, right at the bottom bridge, run into the subway with 1 ZED left running behind you, turn a corner and it is now in your face. I find this to be appaling as it means I have to constantly dodge a single ZED at the end of a round to get ammo, or even worse when you are trying to run away from a scrake and it just appears behind you and saws into your body. At present, there is no desire from TWI to remove this feature (however they do want to fix it up a little). I think that is the most damaging part of this game because it has caused me to stop playing after a single match where I just die from a stray ZED.
- All the music is Christan Metal (Demon Hunter mainly). And whils't that's all well and good, it all feels like it's missing something from the original game. You do have the option to put it to instrumental version only, which is what I have my music set to. It certainly feels closer to the original music style, but still not quite.
- There is no tutorial as of yet for new players to get the hang of the game. It's all done via an online loby or playing solo (both of which can be hard to play in). I'm no fan of tutorials but it'd be nice to see TWI doing something to support the new players instead of just throwing them into the fray.
- In regards to pick ups, if you have full ammo and run over an ammo box you pick it up anyway, making trolls online abundant as they stop everyone from grabbing ammo. Unlike in the original KF, if you ran over an ammo box it would simply tell you that you have max ammo.
- Much of the gameplay feels like a direct copy and paste of the original game (not that that's always a bad thing), but it feels likethey have just simply modified the original game to look a little better and thrown some fancy new perk bonuses in. That may be due to how the weapons work or just overplaying of maps, I don't know.

Right now it simply feels like a Killing Floor 1.5. There is a major lack of content (however it IS early access and people need to be more aware of that) and there are many issues I have with the game itself. Once a few of my cons have been fixed (namely the teleporting ZED issue and more frequent updates) I'll happily change my review to a positive one.
But right now it's a 4/10 for Killing Floor 2, but could easily be changed to a 7/10.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game has become progressively worse and worse.  Tripwire's taken a beautifully simple horde shooter and turned it into an MMO.  Lots of unspoken resistances, weaknesses, nuances, effects, etc.  The best part about it?  They don't even give you the numbers on anything.  If you're going to create an MMO Killing Floor, at least have the etiquette of following MMO format, telling us how much damage we deal, what our percentages are, what the resistances and weaknesses are, etc.  MMO's give us numbers so we can work out what is the most effective way to use our abilities, without hundreds of hours of blind experimentation.

There's nothing less satisfying than laying a C4 trap somewhere, luring big guys into it, and blowing them to kingdom-come, and watching nothing happen.  Oh btw, there's a 50% cumulative damage reduction on each consecutive explosion (they don't tell you this anywhere).  Break the realism and add some crap mechanics.  Great design.  I'm doing a pretty smart tactical maneuver, but I'm 'too smart' for the game and they have to nerf it.  You've got a bad design, then!  Change it!  Tripwire has been talking about adding options and freedom to the way we play, and all they are doing is creating a meta; the exact opposite.

If you want to know what the real meta strategy is for killing a Fleshpound as a demolitionist (according to what I've read): it's to apparently lay a c4, then blow it up, then throw a stick of dynamite on their head to stun them (not sure if 100% chance), then use a rocket launcher on them until they die.  How am I supposed to know that's the magic strategy without reading someone's guide?  If I unload rockets at him, which I would think is the way to do things, since it's a rocket launcher, I just die.  It's not really intuitive or realistic.  Back in KF1, we had a six shooter grenade launcher, and the strategy was to throw down a grenade or two, and then unload the launcher into them.  It was intuitive and simple.

Maybe if I had a lot of feedback and numbers I could piece strategies together.  But the game tells me nothing, it just kills me if I do it wrong, which is a really bad way to do things.  I didn't even know a stick of dynamite stuns a Fleshpound, because the game tells me nothing.  I'm pretty sure it magically starts happening at a certain level, after the point of experimentation.  I  concluded that dynamite does not stun a Fleshpound and was just a quick crowd control device, between reloads.  Then again, maybe I just never landed it on a fleshpound's head.  It has a strange trajectory, throwing like a big upside-down U.  I'm used to throwing grenades in a much straighter manner.

Even Dark Souls has the decency to tell you everything that is going on, so if Tripwire is trying to create a new Dark Souls, they aren't doing it right.  You know exactly why you die, in that game, and that's why players don't mind.  We learn.  This game, there's nothing to learn, because I don't see the programming or numbers at work.  It's blind experimentation.  I only learn if I happen to get lucky and do something right.  I don't even know how much damage my weapons deal, because they just show us some arbitrary bars.  Every weapon is like this.

Anyways, let's get back on track.  The game is becoming grossly convoluted, for a team horde shooter.  I don't like wasting time on super complex games, because they demand way too much of my life.  KF1 was simple, with a bit of complexity.  It was great.  The only weaknesses and resistances I knew of were the Fleshpound weakness to exposives, and the scrakes resistance to explosives.  If there were any more, I didn't need them or they were irrelevent, because I completed most of the game without them.  Most of the skill in that game revolved around headshotting things, and then having the class that countered the bigger guys, which takes a little bit of knowledge.  Sharpshooter was the notoriously broken class, as you had to learn where the broken hitboxes were, in order to headshot and stun things.  Still, it was intuitive, despite the broken hitboxes.

Last point, going back to my theme:  KF1 was not a numbers game.  It was a skill game.  How fast were you at killing?  If you wanted to kill the fastest, you needed to headshot things.  The only numbers you learned as you played were that Fleshpounds were weak to explosives and Scrakes were strong against them.  Everything else was pretty much, shoot it in the head, and watch it die.  Kill fast enough that the horde doesn't reach you.  There wasn't any meta-game to learn.  It was beautifully simple, and the challenge was getting better accuracy, and knowing how to maneuver oneself so that you don't die, if the horde spills over a bit.

KF2 is about damage types and armor types: microwaves, fire, bullets, slashing, bashing, explosive, poison, armor, immunities, resistances, cumulative damage reductions, buffs, blah blah blah.  They also tell you nothing, I've gained all this information from guides and research.

I didn't buy Killing Floor 2 for this.  Not changing my review until Tripwire realizes they have strayed far from the original and made a very convoluted mess.  Then they have to fix it.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Time Bought: 2 months in closed beta, then purchased Early Access release
Money Spent: $40 Digital Deluxe
Worth The Price?: YES
Position In Game At Time Of Review:  After stats wiped after closed beta I still play it every day on 2 steam accounts 5/13/15

Ok first off I'd like to mention that all the negative comments are true, you STILL are not able to kill any floors what so ever in this second installment.  But again it is still in Early Access so maybe that will change!  And they have released the SDK so maybe a modder can change this unfortunate mishap.  Now let's get to the game in general.

Is it like KF1?  Yes and No.  Same kind of gameplay, same people, same zeds, even some of the same maps....but that 2 makes a BIG difference as you will notice MORE blood, MORE skins and gear options, MORE amazing graphic, and lastly MORE ways to kill and dismember every single thing in your way!  And I'm not talking about just the zeds.  The lighting in the room changes as lights blow out.  Zeds can spawn out of manholes right under your feet or even fall into them LOL.  And with the added animations, you will need to actually 'know' or 'feel' the mechanics of the game to perform perfect headshots now.  Even though I still see noobs wasting like 3 pistol clips on a headless bloat o.O lol (wtf, right!?).  You will have to play the game for some time to get the new game mechanics down since they are similar to KF1 but still very different as well.  So far I've spent around 100 hrs to get to know the maps, spawns, reaction times, DIFFERENT ZED MOVEMENTS FROM NORMAL TO HOE, and even different camping places on some maps.  I now feel comfortable swaying away from the 'group' and killing about 100 zeds on Hard on any of the 4 perks to finish out the wave.  The end boss is MUCH more challenging than the Patriarch, but after knowing his 'system' then it get a little bit easier.  But soloing him is not an option unless you read a guide or just get lucky.  The different skins and voice overs are very enjoyable to me since they are all different voiced and say different things each.  I really look forward to all the goofy ones to come in the future :)  All in all, I think this game was worth the $40 pricemark even for an Early Access game.  I play it on a daily regular basis and it's probably only 20% done!!  The gameplay is fluid and alot less glitchy than other EA games I've played.  So I'm pretty sure it will be well worth the price upon final release.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

-One of the best polished early access/Beta games out with content promised & no doubt delivered.

-Great music for this kind of game with and without vocals.

-Graphically outstanding with the best gore effects ive ever seen and solid optimization.

-Very stable with little to no glitches and bugs.

-Would like to know a bit more about the LORE but that will probably be more fleshed (hehe) out in the final version.

-Guns and zeds sound really good although i would prefer the zeds to have some primitive vocals like in killing floor,
the gore effects sound disgusting in all the right ways.

-The occasional comedic relief from the characters is a nice touch.

-AI is good although there is some room to improve.

-Animations are spot on.

-the UI in-game is quite basic, nothing too innovative and nothing to complain about.

-The menu UI on the other hand is great with the classic Zeds popping up in the background.

-The characters are solid with customizable cosmetics.

-The selection of weapons is pretty small but will undoubtedly have additions in the future in great quantities.

-Maps are good and innovative although quite claustrophobic, and more will be added in the future im sure.

-Perks are solid with 4 options for now with sub-perks in 5 level intervals with 2 options each up to level 25,
More perks are guaranteed in the future to up to 10 options.
(http://i.imgur.com/yGGn4d3.jpg?1)

-Graphical options are are plentiful with loads of options and pre-presets.

-Sound options are basic with the added vocal or not music, & minimal character chatter box.

-All in all its a masterpiece for an early access title 9.5/10
