reviewText:
Early Access Review

Killing Floor 2 is the sequel to the wonderous and DLC-loaded Killing Floor 1, which was a great game if what you wanted was a zed-shooting chav convention. Killing Floor was known for its frenetic and panic-ridden atmosphere, along with class-based teamwork orientated combat. Due to the funky mechanics of the game, certain classes were great, other classes were pointless in comparison, and some classes had situational use. The original had 7 classes, whereas Killing Floor 2 promises to deliver on up to 10 or more different classes. Killing Floor 2 does some things better that its predecessor does fairly poorly. I speak, of course, of grinding. The leveling requirements of certain classes meant that although players were encouraged to use mechanics based around the class they chose, it also pigeonholed them into using those features and the game quickly became difficult to endure as hours and hours of grinding were required to reach level 6, the maximum level of a class. Class levels also meant that newer players were outright 'worse' than veteran players, in addition to their lack of experience with the myriad of special enemies. This exacerbated the core issue where certain classes might have appeal to early players but were rapidly outclassed by other classes; this pool includes Commando, easily the weakest class in the game, and Firebug, a class that requires patience and know-how to play effectively, as well as being outclassed in terms of raw damage.

Killing Floor 2 does address some of these issues, splitting the level gain and benefits across 25 levels instead of a mere 6, allowing players to enjoy certain class benefits earlier. However, the currently limited pool of 4 classes left out Sharpshooter, the most important special zed killer of the game, and Demolitionist (or 'demoman'), the go-to blob slaughterer capable of annihilating entire formations of weak zeds. This means that the only way to combat high-threat zeds such as Scrakes or Fleshpounds on equal footing involves going Berserker, a class that has seen better days.

Berserker suffered some nerfs, namely the loss in improved movement speed(no longer true as of  4/23/15), and the loss of the most powerful well-rounded melee weapon, the katana; it is now counted as an offperk weapon avaliable to everyone, and is a bit weaker than its previous incarnation. Berserker's high-risk high-reward fighting style requires incredible amounts of practice to get just right, which is made worse by their weaker damage resistance. Berserkers must now use the new blocking system to be effective, allowing them to push zeds back as a temporary bulwark; notably, this method does not work well against the Fleshpound, which is tougher than any other zed except the bosses. Add to this fact that Fleshpounds now enrage far more readily and do so at any given opportunity, you will find using a Berserker to safely take one down is nothing more than a vain hope. The fact that Berserkers can now be grappled by clots(unless you take a level 10 skill) means you may end up wasting that power attack on a random clot instead of the Scrake you were stunlocking. As before, Berserkers without a medic constantly keeping an eye on them is a dead Berserker.

Support, however, retains much of their staying power with the AA12 and other shotguns; this allows them to maul anything, Scrakes included, into mulch most of the time. However, enemies have a disturbing tendency to 'teleport', sometimes right on top of you, and their shotguns have small magazine size(unchanged from the original) which makes this phenomenon worse. Interestingly enough, the AA12's recoil is far more controllable than the commando's AK-12, with less wavering to the left and right of the target and less muzzle lift during automatic fire.

Medic remains the most important core class comparatively, due to their ability to save team members from certain death. Their medic grenades work just like in the original, putting down a healing field that hurts zeds and is arguably the most useful grenade in the game currently. Their medic weapons are slightly stronger than before, although like Support, Medic has not changed much. The homing healing dart is useful in certain circumstances but given that most enemies 'teleport' to around your general location this may not be as useful as you would hope, as the tracking dart only works if you aim down the sights(no longer) at a player and 'lock on'. As you will be hip-firing at the general location of a zed's head at any given time, you will find that healing darts are the same as before: they require lots of practice and teammates that you can actually count on to let a Medic do their job. Trying to heal a stranger is like trying to hit a target from 100m with a nail gun.

Commando is again the weakest class in the game in terms of raw damage; their assault rifles have very hefty recoil and have a very very bad tendency to go to the left and right of the intended target instead of the target itself. Aiming down the sights makes their weapons a lot more effective; again, chances are you'll be running and aiming down the sights is basically a form of suicide. Due to their lack of firepower, Commandos are comparatively useless early-on until they start benefiting from mid to late-game features such as improved reloading speed. They are a class that requires heavy investment just to become usable, if not useful. If you play a Commando, remember to take a medic pistol and help the poor Medic out. You can spare a few shots of your own so that the Support or Berserker can keep going.

The most major problems with the beta are pathing and 'teleportation'. As someone who has watched more than one B-movie, the serial killer teleportation schtick seems to work somewhat. However, the fact that zeds can teleport INTO YOU, thus displacing your location by sheer happenstance, is incredibly annoying. I've had a bloat spawn right 'under' where I was standing, causing me to stand on top of the Bloat and a large blob of zeds; it then hit me with the bile a microsecond later. The fact that zeds can spawn near or right next to you can prove daunting and dangerous; this problem is made worse by the fact that all zeds benefit from this 'teleport nearer you' ability, preventing you from kiting by sheer dint of literally appearing where you are. On the off-chance a tough enemy or a deadly one such as a Siren, Scrake, or Fleshpound happens to do so, this may result in one or more players dying due to the spawning system.

Pathing in this game was pretty good, until it wasn't. Halfway through the game zeds started 'blinking' past objects by 'walking' on them, thus an inpediment such as a chest-high wall which easily prevents players from jumping over would pose no such challenge to even a Bloat. This is a relatively minor issue until you realize that you have been cornered on Laboratory due to the huge prevalance of chest-high obstructions. Add in the teleporting zeds, and it becomes incredibly easy to get trapped when you shouldn't be.

An issue that is somewhat seperate from the above two is hitboxes. Sometimes a shot that should hit 'flesh' would veer past off into the sunset because the hitbox is very specifically determined; you can test this best by attempting to shoot a Stalker when she does her flip jump. A blast from a shotgun completely missed, with every pellet flying past despite having to have cleanly struck the torso. It may be lag, but given that the next shot took off her head, I doubt it. This is still true as of 4/23/15, unlike the berserker movespeed.

As expected of a beta, the game has many issues, although it certainly brings back the zed-killing fun and does a great job with the level system. Get it now if you want to try out the wonky engine, or get it later when Sharpshooter gets added in. The new character-specific voices are a great addition, although the lack of the colliqual 'Dosh' is a bummer.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Killing Floor 2:
~~~~~~~~~~~

Are you ready to take your place in a small team of six soldiers? Be ready to look out for each other when the waves of ‚ÄúZeds‚Äù are coming at you from each side of the hexagon? Oh dear‚Ä¶. The first wave is coming at us‚Ä¶ Get ready to Zumble!

Killing Floor 2 is a co-op FPS game where you take control of one of six characters and try to eliminate wave after wave (between 7 to 10 waves, depending on which server you are playing) of Zeds until you face either the ‚ÄúPatriach‚Äù - this scary and rather large mutated zombie/robot/Hulk thingy who has a rather heavy arsenal and is very strong in melee combat , or ‚ÄúHans Volter‚Äù- the Nazi evil doctor who is holding himself pretty well for his age (he is around 100 years old) and likes to throw Toxic and High Explosive grenades! But don‚Äôt give him a chance to cuddle you as he will squeeze the life out of you to regenerate his own!

But before you get to the bosses you will face eleven types of ‚ÄúZeds‚Äù, some will be easy to eradicate and some will be rather tough. At the end of each wave, you will be directed to a specific pod (there are several pods per map) where you will be able to buy ammunition, weapons and armour. Every kill you get is more money to spend at the pod! You have 40 different weapons you can use in this game; each weapon will fall into one of 7 categories ‚Äì Beserker ‚Äì Commando ‚Äì Support ‚Äì Field Medic- Demolition ‚Äì Gunslinger and Firebug weapons. Whatever you use, at the end of the game you will get points for it. For example, only use a hunting shotgun (I doubt you will do that) and you will level up your support category faster than the others.

10 original maps to play in, from Burning Paris to the Catacombs passing by the Farmhouse; they are all very good and well designed. Some are bigger than others but equally as fun and challenging.

From the difficulty point of view, it will depend on which server you will be playing but you will be able to choose between Normal, Hard and Suicidal.

Graphically, this game is fabulously detailed and it runs very well. I enjoy the slow motion effect too, it‚Äôs just great! If you like heavy metal, the soundtrack is really good and fits the game perfectly. It‚Äôs hectic!

Positives:
~~~~~~~

-	Great and fun co-op FPS game
-	10 maps to play in
-	40 weapons to use
-	Great re-playability
-	Great graphics & soundtrack
-	Achievements & Trading cards

Negatives:
~~~~~~~~

-	A bit repetitive I must say

Killing Floor 2 is fun, it‚Äôs fast and full of Zeds!!

9/10

Key provided by developer/publisher for review purposes. Any opinions expressed are entirely my own!

Killing Floor is one of a few marvelous cooperative shooters where you and friends face off against waves of enemies. With a selection of different perks/classes and weaponry, up to six players can engage in some zed killing fun, and lord knows I spent quite some time playing 1 before I moved on to 2. Killing Floor 2 had from early access promised to be more of that, however as it stands I can't recomend this game to anyone.

Still in early access, unfinished as I write this review, the updates have been progressing at a rate akin to watching a glacier melt.  While that could be overlooked, theres no overlooking its attempt to impliment a microtransaction system to the game before its even finished. Some would argue that the items gained from said microtransaction system are purely cosmetic and thus could be ignored. This is true, however, this ignores the fact that this system works off once again a lotterly similair to TF2, CS: GO, and now Payday2: a microtransaction system that is less convienent for players wanting to get cosmetics and more for Tripwire's profits.

For those not familiar with this system: on occassion you will receive a loot crate" (or "blueprint" in this case) that requires a "key".  The only means to get this key of course involves a fee using your real money.  Once said transaction takes place

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game is not worth buying at the moment. At least not if you're like me who expected to play it for hundreds of hours like Killing Floor 1.

While this game is pretty and some of the guns are well designed, the gameplay gets boring fast. There are no interesting combos to kill big zeds like there was in KF1. No nade chaining, no flinching, no siren cancelling, no precise and time-sensitive combos. Parrying seemed to have some promise at the beginning of EA (v1008), but it's useless now with the introduction of unparriable attacks. The meta is just shoot it til it dies.

Support was my favorite perk in KF1 and it is now sadly underpowered with little ammo, low-damage weapons and a VERY underwhelming double barrel shotgun. Demo is also garbage with the first 2 tier weapons, and the insane C4 stacked damage dropoff; plus instead of the amazing M32 we got an RPG. Firebug and zerk are OP and boring; they don't even require skill with their spam-M1-to-win weapons. Commando used to be very good and fun during v1008 but requires an ammo buff now. Medic and gunslinger are alright I guess.


Updates take months. They can't even bother to release frequent balance tweaks. You have to wait months for the big update to see if the sequel to your favorite game is interesting to play again (hint: I'm still waiting).

Now this is just nothing compared to the insult of purchasing this game on Early Access under the premise that TWI was going to do it right"

Early Access Review

I want to like this game, but the developers have time and time again abused the trust of their customers. Moderators take down any threads on the Steam forums that have criticism, legitimate or not. -Microtransactions

reviewText:
Early Access Review

It saddens me to give this one the thumbs down guys but I've uninstalled the game today and don't forsee re-installing unless there are dramatic changes.

As many reviews have already mentioned, the developers have taken a path to completion that is meandering into territory that is unwanted. Traditionally Killing Floor has always been about a solid class based co-op experience (PvE) and now there is a focus on PvP (humans versus Zed) which in my opinion is problematic - especially at this stage of development - because it has the potential to impact PvE in terms of class/perk abilities i.e. balance decisions as well as taking away developer time that could be used to complete the core game instead (updates are slow).

It seems like at some point during development a decision was made to try incorporate features from other titles such as CS:GO and Left 4 dead which again, in my opinion have no place in the KF2 arena. These features are key/crate purchase systems and the Player verus Player aspect of L4D with humans versus special infected. Instead of focusing on what made Killing Floor 1 at least somewhat unique with systems like the door welding and the gritty atmosphere, Killing Floor 2 is trying to be everything to everyone and that's simply not going to work.

What they did try to take from Killing Floor 1 is currently broken. Door welding (a tactic to barricade yourself from the hordes for a while) is meaningless because of the Zed teleportation feature" whereby Zeds too far from players will be teleported to a nearby location to the players where no-one is currently looking. Think that corner was safe a second ago? Well look away for a second and surprise - in your face pal - as a Zed suddenly occupies that space and wastes no time in hacking people - that thought they were safe -  to death. Not fun and so many people have complained about this it appears that Devs are not going to address it any time soon - if at all.

Weapon choices are very limited. The perk/class abilities are not all that interesting and really could use a complete overhaul to allow for more combo-play to encourage team-work and up the skill ceiling a bit. It would be much more interesting for perks from one class to directly link-up with perks from another class to deal more damage to enemies or create some other useful defensive effects.

As a PC gamer I am also not pleased to see obvious consolization creep into this title. Chat wheels instead of the key-bound menu drill down from Killing Floor 1
date: welders only appearing when you are near a door
recommended: auto-aim medic healing darts etc. These all impact the PC experience negatively.\n\nSo
hoursPlayed: I rather like the music and graphics in this game - at least those are good in my opinion but not enough to save it.\n\nIt is my opinion that you'd be much better off buying Killing Floor 1 at this point even though it is quite a bit older now - the gameplay is so much better."

Overall, I enjoy it, i've been able to play with each of the six classes so far in to get a feeling of them, and how they are independent and have their own important roles. I've only found one little issue with the game... Well, it's not so little, its game breaking, and I mean literally! The game has some serious compatibility issues, and usually take a few months to have ironed out. For example, right now it is saying  Steam is required to play this game,[puu.sh] but as soon as I press okay, it closes. I've looked for ways to solve this for hours, and the only one(which is not fully confirmed) is to reinstall steam itself, which has hundreds of gigabytes of information. reviewText:
Early Access Review

So, I'm going to start by saying I loved KF1 and had around 1000 hours across different accounts. So before the toxic community white knights start their ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•t, I'll start with the positives of Killing Floor 2:
-The graphics looks somewhat better compared to the first game in some areas, for example, in Burning paris you actually see the buring Eiffel, and the map is destructible when it comes to lights.
-The characters look better, but on the same note, I feel that their lore is rather lacking compared to the funny bios we got in the first game
-Some of the zeds actually look better, and others, not so much.
And now for the part nobody wants to read, the negatives:
-Horribly balanced perks to the point that 2 of them are HOE meta since there's no need for the others. (Beserker, Medic)
-A completely pointless welder since they decided to add in perma breaking doors, where as in the first game, the welder had a purpose
-Maps are somewhat poorly designed in layout due to the fact that there's always one point to hole up in
-The AI is god awful when it comes to the ability to zerk wall as it targets the players behind the beserkers rather than the beserkers themselves which sets up for the 2 perk meta I mentioned above
-The gunplay in this game feels really weak, like super soaker weak when it comes to hitting the big guys
-The teleportation is incredibly annoying and game breaking when you need to run away and heal and then the thing you were running away from appears in front of you effectively ruining the point of kiting/evasion recovery tactics
-The scrake and fleshpound went from logical mechanics to bullet sponges, even with explosives
-The game feels really arcadey and overly casual compared to it's prequel
-The trader is now just a pod, rather than a person
-Some of the VA is really awful, even by Killing Floor standards
-The music isn't really fitting when it comes to song choice, it just feels cheesy
-Aside from the zerk wall meta mentioned previously, there isn't really any teamplay aside from spraying the bullet sponges with super soakers
-The MT system is pretty trash, where as the DLC system in the first game was perfect for what was delivered
-The update times are incredibly long and quite laughable for what's delivered on an update day

Overall I'd rate this a 4/10 for obvious reasons.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I really wanted to like this game, so I've given it a good run of play and a lot of chances to improve before writing a review. I really enjoyed Killing Floor 1 and thought it was great value for money. I think I paid $10 for it, and got 400 hours of play out of it, through interesting mods, piles of great custom maps, plenty of servers, and of course interesting player classes and a nicely balanced diffculty curve that my friends and I gladually climbed. Killing Floor 2 cuts right back on a lot of that.

I bought KF2 in early access because I enjoyed KF1 so much and wanted to support the guys who made such a fun game. I've had it for what's got to be coming up on a year now, and they've done very little with the game in that time. There is a paltry selection of official maps, which is my cheif complaint. This kind of game lives or dies through the ability to freshen things up by playing regular new maps. They're decent, but there's nowhere near enough. On top of that, there are very few servers that run custom maps. It gets very bland, samey and tedious going over the same few maps on every server.

Next there's the character classes. This is a minor complaint, but they've all been simplied and streamlined since KF1. The carrying capacity and small number of weapons for each class really limits players and doesn't allow any real space to customise your loadout to your particular play style. You pretty much just go for the top weapon and that's it. I feel like KF1 gave you a bit more freedom to match weapon loadout to your preferred play style for a particular character, and I expected KF2 to give more freedom there, as a sequel, not less.

Then there's the difficulty curve, which is a big problem. It's just stupidly unbalanced. My friends and I have progressed through normal and hard, and both of those are too easy for us now, but the next rank: suicidal, is just silly. And that's not even the hardest difficulty. We're damn good players, but it's frustratingly hard, to the point of draining the fun from the game.  So we're stuck in this no-man's land where hard is too easy and suicidal is so difficult it's not worth it. The game needs major balancing, but the patches are few and far between. It's like trip wire have just given up and are content to make money off of DLC and microtransactions while leaving the game in early access forever. Levelling up your character to 25 doesn't help either, since the level 25 perks are universally almost useless for each character class, which is bizarre. You'd think that achieving top level with your character would warrant a big reward, but the focus on 'Zed-time' means you -might- get two seconds worth of use out of this perk every 30 seconds or so if you're lucky, and the bonuses are pretty poor. It adds almost nothing to the game.

With the current state of the game's balance, the lack of maps, and the VERY slow rate of patching and updates I honestly can't recommend this game unless it's on sale really cheaply... and even then I'm not sure tripwire deserve to be rewarded for leaving this game and its players in limbo.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Teamwork over personal skills"
*** I will complete my review in several steps. Try to explain my concerns / points why I cannot recommend this game ***

Microtransactions
For actual reasons I just wanna to say those so-called microtransactions are not real ones. Neither you have a P2W model nor the gameplay is affected at all. It's rather the crate/key concept (already known from other games) with just cosmetical items and even random free drops. But I still do not support this in order to let the ppl not get used to an overated market and a gambling zone around honestly worthless key items (-)

Introduction
Killing Floor 2 is the highly anticipated sequel to Killing Floor. I've played Killing Floor for almost 2k hours and it is still a great game with a huge fanbase. As you can imagine the devs tried basically to keep this successful concept but also to polishup their graphics
hoursPlayed:
bosses and maps at the same time. All things the devs said / promised you can easily checkup in the official trailers and making-of videos. The game is still EA. So that doesn't mean anything cannot be changed at all. Instead of complaining I backup that the game is permanently evolving after a very successful beta launch (+)

Graphics / Sound
The devs said it's an Unreal 3.5 Engine means they pimpedup the Unreal3 Engine to max to visualize what they couldn't do in KF1. The graphics are just brilliant. If you have seen them once you don't wanna go back to KF1. It has a legacy to mess with actual titles like Evolve and is even superperformant on some older PCs since the first minute of playing. The new Zed-time
voteText: the 3D animations of Zeds and weapons
helpfulPercent:
the maps and even the MP characters are state of the art and brilliant implemented. The Metal soundtrack by Zyntetic / Demon Hunter fits perfectly into a picture of a great game (++)

Gameplay
Unfortunately the gameplay has changed entirely. Ofc you still have the waves and the "weapon-buy-earn-dosh-through-killing" concept. The devs said they wanted the game at least to become more kiteable. But in fact camping in "turtle strategy" brings mostly the success on higher difficulties. Partly it's a degrading of perk autonomy into a roleplaying game. Zerk always blocks in frontline. Other perks hideout behind him in a tight place. The good old times when a zerk was able to kite a sc/fp or an entire wave on his own are gone. Mostly annoying are the introduced QTEs when a clot suddenly grabs you first have to dash him away. Dumb if you are already chased by a raging fp and now it hammers you away (- -)

Zeds
The 3D models were all redesigned. Now they look more scary and dangerous except the new Clot (lol?). Basically they look wider and blocky. During Gameplay they can even block your way at all places
votesHelpful:
they spawn and shortcut around you and surround you instantly. The Zeds got new animations and mechanics. All Zeds have extended  fightmodes on sui/hoe and also a perma run/rage mode. Looks like a gorefast can strike you 4 times in a row if you don't parry his attacks. Also Zed bodies have become more bulletspongey. Because of more hitboxes you have to do several shots before they go down. That means you better have to concentrate on headshots all the time (-)

Bossfights
Bossfights are insanely hard and long. The bosses are very resistant. Each boss has 3 phases of surviving before you can knock him down. Mostly you loose your teammates before the last phasis is reached. Hans Volter has even an invulnerability in his intermediate lifesucking phasis. The Patriarch keeps on being invisible most of the time. Needs a certain strategy and almost more than a load of full magazines of each teammate to beat the boss in the end. Also nervewracking is a new running mode of your character (not only on bossfights). So you keep on running on bossfights for about a quarter til a half hour (-)

Perks
What is new that are levelperks. Each 5 level you will get an extra perk ability. 25 levels / perk
votesTotal:
7 perks atm (10 perks are planned). The devs said they wanted to reduce the uplevel perk grinding. They barely did it. It still take ages to uplevel. Even if there are no more cross-perk weapon use punishments. Actually you levelup your weapons for using them and gain also xp for total damage. They also added achievements for each levelperk which shows that fast perkleveling has become the new aim.
Ofc the weapons must fit into the new gameplay means "headshooter weapons" required for each perk. Unfortunately there's no Sharpshooter yet (which can takeout the big ones with a few headshots). The new gunslinger perk and his dual wielding akimbo style weapons is rather comparable with a demo in his effectiveness. He can blast through heads but has the slowest reload times. So Sc / Fp is still a problem for him (-)

Weapons
Weapons are the essential part of the game. The devs wanted them to be more realistic
votesFunny: great feeling and handling during gameplay and engaged even Pro RL shooters for fast magazine exchanges recorded by motion capturing. Though p.e. the Commando Bullhup got improved and feels way more decent
commentsCount: other weapons seem more unprecisely or bulletconsuming due to more detailed Zed-animation / dodging and own accurancy while running / turning around. Some weapons got even miniaturized / lowpowered like pipebombs and the flying sawblade which doesn't make it easier. Positive are all new medic weapons and also the firebug has a smashing microwave device. Demolition has only 1 shot magazine weapons. And the new Gunslinger shots through masses with his double magnums. The biggest issue is that reload takes insanely long. Over 3 secs in some cases. Even if the animation is nice
column16:
mostly it's your death. Also buggy: if you start a reload animation and dash in the meanwhile a Zed away you must start it all over again. It does not do anything in the background. Same with healing (+-)

Weapon Combos
In KF2 I havent seen any of them. Except the fast run around a Sc glitch. Surely you are able with a zerk attack parry and some other weapons to bring the big ones shortly to stumble. But a secondary knockdown would be nice. In KF1 there was this uppercut combo as a Support. Like stun / flinch with katana + blast the head with the double barrel shootgun (-)

Conclusion (temporarly)
You can enjoy these brandnew exciting graphics and proceed on some maps. Lots of stuff is still coming in. But for the moment I feel a bit disappointed that I cannot play as used through the maps. Seems I need to learn a gameconcept that doesn't feel comfortable to me."

This game looks nice. The gore system is all there. As a GTX 980 owner, Nvidia really did well with the FleX system. Everything is very beautiful to shoot. Popping a Zed's head is always a treat. The Zed Time contrast effect is very pretty and gives you much needed seconds to line up a trio of shots on a Siren before she can open her creepy scream-hole.

The sound design is excellent as well! Shotguns sound like god slamming his car door. The healing grenades are MUCH more pronounced, a definite improvement over KF1. The music choice is somewhat...meh. I've never been too much of a metal head, but I muted them rather quickly. The same riff sawing away in your ears gets old relatively fast and the tracks all sound far too much alike. The character vocalization is fun. Though I will admit the Reverend is really irritating with his hurt sounds. reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nThis is a game that is not just for it's fan's but also for fresh blood alike. Amazing game in terms of an FPS experience, just the right amount of urgency, raw firepower and skill are needed to wrangle with this wild horse. A polished, simple and enjoyable skill intensive shooter. Although it is supposed to be aimed somewhat at horror, it falls short. The melee class has been hurt severely from the original game, more so that what I would call balancing, not to mention a crappy final weapon. The AI for the mobs could use a little more work on pathfinding and player target promotion. It however more than delivers on a 'bloody' good time when gore settings are at maximum. The handling is amazing, as is expected of the Unreal engine, smooth and precise. The game has become so beautiful that it's scare factor is all but gone, perhaps more creative future maps and game play modes will address this as the genre intended. Top marks for this game (and it's still incomplete). Keep it up Tripwire!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I know I have a decent amount of hours put into this game, but let me explain my reasoning as to why I don't believe you should be buying this game now.

While, at its most basic, Killing Floor 2 manages to retain a good amount of what made the first Killing Floor fun, the horrible way in which Tripwire has handled this game because of its Early Access tag definitely doesn't make the game worth it at its current moment, which revolves around the same problem: Tripwire wanting polished updates when they are released, but taking the idea too far with it. I'll go into detail about what this means:

First off, small patches to well-known bugs never happen unless they are completely game-breaking. If you find a bug in the game that's annoying and recurs in every other game - too bad! You have to wait months for the content update to get that small fix. Expect to play with that and many other bugs for months.

By extension, this also applies to balance in the game itself. Is a weapon, a perk, or a skill, too underpowered or too overpowered? Suck it up for the next few months. Tripwire makes absolutely no attempts at rebalancing their game at all either for the time between two content updates, so you are stuck with a metagame that may make the game either too easy or too hard and there's no changing that for a long time (and this already happened: the current state of Hell on Earth, the highest difficulty in the game, is pretty much a joke because of the amount of broken weapons and skills you have access to that make it a ton easier than it's supposed to be. This has been the case for 3 months now).

Now, when it comes to my two former points, understand that this is not complaining about the game having bugs or having balance issues in itself. These things are to be expected, especially in an Early Access game. The problem, as I already mentioned, is that these things are woefully ignored, or at least it seems that way. It doesn't matter that the majority of the community reports a problem or asks for a change to something - it is simply not happening until Tripwire feels like finally letting it out. This leads to stagnation of the game, and in turn, to it feeling boring sooner or later, especially given how the game is still lacking a good amount of content which just makes the problem worse.

But don't let me finish this without stating the most controversial topic that has recently surfaced about this game: microtransactions being added to a game that's not even close to finished yet. Of course, as of now, these microtransactions only provide you with cosmetic items which don't affect gameplay at all, which is obviously a good thing. However, it's still really questionable that a game that isn't even finished yet attempts to milk you for more money. On top of that, they have explicitly said they were considering adding gameplay-changing DLC in the future (which is just adding insult to injury). And of course, all of this is given out with the excuse that they want community feedback, yet, like I stated earlier, feedback on bugs or balance in the game (arguably, aspects that are much more important to the game) appears to fall into deaf ears.

Finally, when you are already starving for content for the game, you find out that the update they were working on has already been given to journalists so they can play it first before you, the paying customer of Early Access. And what's the release date on this update that journalists already played? Don't know. Some ambiguous date that still doesn't let you know when to expect it.

So what point am I trying to make with all this? That if you are buying Early Access to contribute to the game's development, know that your input is likely to not make a difference. If you are buying it because you want to experience each change in the game as it comes out, know that you are going to be waiting a really long time between these changes, and the more-or-less $30 that you put down for it is still not gonna be as worth it to the devs as that guy who writes articles to review games, who is going to get it first and eat the cake in front of you while you stare, drooling and not being able to do anything about it. Because you, the customer, are not that important. And, if you are buying it just because you wanna play a fun game, know that you are likely to run into a lot of bugs and balance problems that will sour the game while seemingly nothing is done about it.

I will change my review of this game when and if steps are taken by the developers to change the way things are now. Otherwise, just wait for the full release of the game when you can make an informed decision.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Killing Floor 2 is the sequel to a a horror based horde style first person shooter. The game follows its predecessor close, with the only major difference being an upgraded engine that makes it look like a gorgeous reason to upgrade your computer. Its a gory game and that's one of the reasons why you play, for the sheer beauty of how gruesome it is. There is no subtlety to the game, you are getting rushed by monsters in waves and its action and combat heavy. Even in early access, the game feels polished, refined and finished even with six maps. The menus and shop interface that make it so much better. It makes all the difference and makes the game more approachable than the previous one.

When you step in, its almost like a haunted house, you get in, you have your fun, then you go on your merry way. You can just turn off your brain and enemies will come to you. There's no puzzles to solve or any single player campaign, just action wave after wave. To the game's credit, its easy to select a match from a server and when one game ends, you all vote on the next map to play.

The game controls nice on a mouse and keyboard or a 360 controller. It controls like a lot of similar first person shooters. You have iron sights, a throw button for money or weapons, holding one button lets you select from your inventory of things, there's a quick heal, jump, run, alt-fire, reload and a crouch that almost feels useless. Commandos also have night vision or and everyone else has a flashlight depending on the weapon. The night vision only lasts for a limited duration, but it does the trick, until you can find your way to a bright area.

In terms of equipment, you have primary weapons, secondary pistols, melee weapons, a med kit to get you quick healed and a welder. While I know the welder is used to seal doors shut, I never see many people using it. Perhaps some would rather have mobility to escape a room that's full of monsters rather than creating bottlenecks so there are less entries. Each weapon has its own stats for damage, range, firing rate, bashing, reloading speed and ammo capacity,

The stats between tiers of guns seem minimum at best for the cost. Its still good to buy extra guns due to your maximum ammo capacity. The more waves you face, the more bullets you'll need for your foes. There are still glowing green ammo boxes here and there.

Between each wave of enemies, a store will open up and a path will show you the way to ensure that you find it after a jog. The store is only open around a minute, but it feels like enough time. I have a feeling that the real reason for shops opening up in different locations is to encourage you play different parts of the map. I've seen a lot of games where players just hustle back to the biggest area to fight enemies.

At the store you can spend credits to refill your ammunition and body armor. You can also purchase new weapons that stay with you until you die or the match ends. If someone else on your team is dead, they will drop a weapon for the next person to pick up. There is still a way to throw a weapon on the ground as well as money for anyone that needs it.

Between games and even waves, you can select your perk from one of six. They include a berserker that's geared more toward melee weapons, the commando who prefers assault rifles and grenades. The support class starts you with a shotgun and a frag. The field medic begins with a restoration gun and medical grenades to heal allies. The demolition perk has a stick of dynamite and a grenade pistol from the start. Last up is the firebug that can only use spears and torches. No, the perk uses fire and Molotov cocktails.

These perks start you off with select weapons, but you can still use a weapon from any class. Any perk class can use any weapon and you can level up with any weapon. Every five levels, a new ability gets unlocked, but for the most part perks include passive benefits. Some grant you more health or damage, others have quicker welding speed. To get more experience to level up, you need to kill enemies with weapons from the class. There are other ways to increase experience, but that's the bluntest way.

While the game is designed for online multiplayer, there is a single player option for offline practice or if you just like the challenge of being the lone survivor. When a game starts, you chose your difficulty, map, amount of waves and perks. There are only a few maps, but in a game whose predecessor had ludicrous levels of downloadable content, I expect the same here. You can still have a lot of fun on the game's six or so maps.

Each map is laden with details and offers a few arenas with multiple entryways. Even with a team of six, there's still a lot of potential for something to sneak up behind you. Its okay though, because having five teammates ensures that someone is always watching your back by sheer coincidence.

Each monster is a gruesome piece of art. Hairless naked zombies, obese men with two butcher knives with brown stained bottoms and green boils that vomit green chunks to cover the screen and blind you. Darkened black mutants with spider legs extending out of their back who crawl on the floor below your sight lines or  on a ceiling above you. There's a siren that walks slow and does radius damage with her shriek. Men with one arm, no flesh who have a sword instead of a hand that scrapes long the floor.

Wave after wave, the enemies keep getting larger and tougher. Giant mutants with a chainsaw arm start appearing. They dance and whirl as they chase after you trying to smash their saw in your back. There are giant bruisers with huge metal hands that use them to block your gunfire as they chase after you. It all crescendos with the final wave and a boss fight. One last tank that just sponges bullets and challenges the entire team.

The game makes excellent use of its gore. Limbs fly off with explosions and a headshot will explode a head, but a headless body can still shamble around, but usually a bullet to the head will drop an enemy. Intestines will explode out of the big guys. Sometimes everything will slow down so you can take in the atmosphere as its painted. The slow motion also helps with aim.

When you die, you're out for the wave. If your team survives, you're back in the game. its a system that prevents exploiting if you lose, you drop out and reenter. The game lets you spectate who is still playing to still keep you interested.

For those that like customization, you can customize a lot of things on your character when it comes to the look. You pick a person, select from a brief list of faces and clothing textures then select what's on their face. Its deep enough to be enjoyable, but shallow enough without getting lost in the details. The real reason to change characters is for when you get bored of their voice overs. There are no skills that differ between them, because that's reserved for the perk system.

The soundtrack has a mix of big metal songs and tense tracks that would get found in a modern horror movie. It has almost as much thrash metal than Brutal Legend. The voice acting is high quality, but you'll hear the same French woman who runs the store telling you her pod is open or when it can open. There might be a lot of one liners, but you'll hear them all quick enough before you change characters. The enemies make believable noises while you're looking at them, but even foes that make loud growls can still go silent enough to surprise you.

Killing Floor 2 excels in the gore and the easy to drop in or drop out aspect. its fun to play, but without a set goal of a campaign it might turn people off. Its easy to find a match and keep playing without breaking the flow. While the game supports six players at once, it still feels like you can still do your own thing on lesser difficulties. You can still make it through on your own, until a huge mob of later wave enemies sneaks up from behind pins you to the wall.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Initially, I was very excited for a sequel to one of my favorite FPS games of all time. Sadly, however, while I understand the game is still unfinished, it just really pales in comparison to its predecessor in many ways.

Now, even though this is a negative review, let me state that Killing Floor 2 is not a bad game in its own right; it's just a bad sequel. If you've never played the first Killing Floor and jump into this game, you'll probably have a great time. On its own, Killing Floor 2 is a fast-paced, hoard mode style shooter with great graphics, beautiful guns and satisfying gore. Compared to the first game, however, its core gameplay loop is very rough and unpolished, with fights quickly devolving into wars of attrition where you hope your team's lead output is great enough to stem the tide. It feels way too chaotic and makes strategy and tactics feel worthless. With time, this roughness may be ironed out, but I feel like it shouldn't have been that way to begin with.

Another big problem with the game is the slow pace of updates. This wasn't an issue back in the KF1 days since the game was already super fun, but this game desperately needs more polish and more content injections; an update every 3 months isn't going to hold people's interest for long when the core gameplay just isn't all that great. It's looking less and less likely that this game will be ready for its intended launch date. The game is also starting to show symptoms of feature creep, with new guns and perks being set aside for things like Vs. survival. Why not get all the promised content in the game before adding new game modes that will require tons of tweaking before they get to a point where people actually want to play them?

Overall, as much as it pains me to say, I just can't recommend Killing Floor 2 in its current state. Perhaps in a year or two it will be in a much better place, but I'm worried that by then there won't be many people left playing. I would highly suggest checking out the first game instead; it may have a small community now, but it's frankly a much better experience right now.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

As of right now... no I wouldn't want to recommend Killing Floor 2 until it's out of Early Access. Unless you really really loved the KF1,  but wanted a bit more, and you can live without the campiness. (Although they have classic skins with the two original male voices).

I love both games and I'll still be playing after this review, however it's just sad how even on the Early Access part that Tripwire said they'll be doing it right. Yes you can ignore microtransactions, but what people seem to not understand is how bad of taste microtransactions left in gamers mouths. I'm all for supporting devs, but the best support they can get is new players purchasing their game. That's pretty much how KF1 got so popular (Also getting a PC powerful enough to run that wouldn't be that expensive, oh and can't forget steam sales).

Versus is all right, if you've played L4D well with great teamwork then you should have no trouble with this. However I'd like the rest of the perks in. There is the workshop so maps aren't going to be too much of an issue, unless modders add perks themselves.

So overall the game is great, however it definitely feels like Tripwire is giving it a second thought, although they are still holding mapping contests it seems. Enemies are fun to fight, guns are fun to use, current perks as well. But it just needs those final perks and maps. Honestly less skins and cosmetics would be nice until this gets out of EA.

TL;DR I love the game but can't recommend it like I could do for Killing Floor 1. I can only hope the final release is better than what we have now

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Wouldn't recommend getting this game at full price since there is so little content. I bought this when it first became available but until now there hasn't been much that has been added imo. If the developers do intend on coming out with more jobs/bosses in this game you might have to wait a very long time. (where did sharpshooters go?). Also, without further content the game feels a little too repetitive (only one boss, highly predictable). However if you have played the first game, I would have to say the graphics improvement is pretty awesome and gameplay feels much smoother than the first one.

But is it worth it for the full price? My advice is to wait until they have completed the game and then you can judge if the game is worth it for yourself. It is an early access game first and foremost. I don't feel like it is being given enough updates and support for fans of the game who have purchased in full price to fund the development of this game.

Also, microtransactions. These microtransactions that do not affect gameplay and only for cosmetic purposes That is entirely fine with me. But why microtransactions when the game isn't even completed yet? Additionally, eventually there may be others that will affect gameplay and that I will not support. Paying this much money for a fraction of the game and having to pay more in order to deal more damage in the game pr some other effect? no thanks. Paid for a full game, expecting a full game FIRST.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

1st Review:
It pains me to say it, but because of recent events, I can no longer whole heartedly recommend this game now or (Seemingly) anytime in the future. Killing Floor 2 has potential even though since it's inception, has deviated from the path of Killing Floor 1. I had my suspicions of bad things to come since the 2nd Dev Diary, and those suspicions ended up being true.

Tripwire Interactive never stated that the use of Microtransactions would be part of the core mechanic of the game, and had never pitchd the idea to the community. I would rather have DLC skin packs after the full release of the game. The use of the 'CS:GO' strategy is unfavorable, regardless of whether or not the items affect the gameplay. It's nothing more than an attempt to create an in-game economy that encourages heavy spending on the 'Possibility' of getting an item you want.

I am excited about all the other content, I've been looking forwards to it for a long while now. I'm likely to be playing after the patch in order to gauge a proper opinion on the new perks and weapons. Although I'll be playing to form an opinion, I will not change my mind over the Microtransaction implimentation.

Early Access Review

The game looks great and is fun with a decent amount of content, with most of the core in place. Unfortunately the developers are insisting on a RNG stlye DLC moving forwards regardless of the fact that the core is still incomplete, claiming that it's the best thing in order to support the players with free content as opposed to the true reason of stuffing their pockets.

As much as I would like to reccomend this game, I simply can't. Sure it's fun for a while, but until the game is near completion (i.e. when all perks are in game, and only balancing remains) I would not reccomend it, as we cannot sure how much content the developers will be willing to push into the RNG DLC.

Perhaps look back at this game in a few months time to see if anything has changed. Updates are released approximately once every 3 months, so all of the perks may have made it into the game within the next year or so.

To clear things up, I am not opposed to DLC. I actually purchased every single DLC for Killing Floor 1, but I will not support paying for a chance" of getting what I want."

reviewText:
Early Access Review

There are some bad gameplay mechanics that I hope get changed in future patches (if they actually still work on more content, considering how little they update).
Some lights can break and stay broken (doors also stay broken) which is usually annoying (grenades, berserkers, demos will destroy them by accident or people will troll by destroying them in public games).
Kiting Fleshpounds has changed and doesn't work the way you would expect if you played the first game.
You have to let the Hans Volter boss grab you 3 times in order to remove his shield each time, making solo a lot harder.
Other than that I couldn't really get into the game and it feels quite different, maybe I expected too much after coming from KF1.

Gameplay aside, instead of providing long-awaited real content already, they decided to announce microtransactions for a game that is still in early access. Furthermore there may be gameplay-changing microtransactions in the future, as you can read here.[killingfloor2.com]
I suggest to go play the first Killing Floor instead.



Edit:
I still have a few other points about the game to add.
There are already weapons you can only unlock by owning another game (Claymore for example). This may give a gameplay advantage to players who are not owning it.
Medic darts have become too easy, no need to try to aim anymore.
The new Patriarch design which got released recently is.. very curious and surely not what you would expect to be the Patriarch.
Oh and lastly, if by their definition you show abusive behaviour, they can simply revoke your CD key, according to the EULA. This may not sound that bad at first, but should they apply SJW definitions for abusive behaviour, anything can be offensive.

The first experience was good. I have a four-years-old PC and fortunately it can run the 'Killing Floor 2'. Although, I had to taken-down most of the graphics options, but now, it's run quite well.

Buy armor, oh mon Dieu. / Look at you, go find a medic! / You've earned some money, spend it.

I know the rookies need some help, but... oh, mon Dieu, just make a turorial texts like in 'Killing Floor 1'!

Bad things:

-It is 'Early Access' game, so there are a few crash both of client and server.

I recommend this game those who have played the 'Killign Floor 1' and like it, and those who likes the co-op first-person-shooter games.

Zeds teleport infront of you every 10-25 seconds making it impossible to play on maps with tight corridors and stuff.

Poor map design, there is so much spots on the map which allow you to make zeds come from only one entrence and then making a berserker sit on that entrence making it impossible for zeds to enter, so on maps like prison, farmhouse and maybe even outpost and catacombs the whole game becomes standing behind a berserker blocking a door and shooting the zeds that are hitting the berserker.

Crappy zed moviment, they constantly zig zag for no reason making you miss and thus making combat annoying, they can turn 180 degrees in less than a quarter of a second, causing classes like support and demo to waste a lot of valueble ammo and overall making it painful to try and hit zeds, especially giants (scrakes and fleshpounds, the two most dangerous enemies other than the 2 bosses) that already take a lot of hits to put down.

The end boss Hans is broken, in a 6 man Hell on earth server he kills players in 2 melee hits, is overall boring to fight because of the invulnerable states he gets into when you deal enough damage and then he goes trying to catch a player to heal on (he doesnt actually heal, its staged and I think they only made it to make him more interesting) but the problem is when he goes into this state he can sometimes hit you and kill you instead of grabbing you and theres no way you can avoid that.

Maps that allow you to level up faster that in the end makes players that are lvl 25 that dont know the basics of the game.

And theres also stupid little things that suck but dont really matter like boring achievements (reach lvl 5 with the medic, reach level 10 with the medic, reach level 15 with the medic and so on, this goes on for every class, leveling up takes a lot of time and is not really fun.) expensive cosmetics, i thought these items they added were to give you the ability to customize your character how you like but some items that look cool cost like 20 euros which blows.

A sequel like killing floor 2 is supposed to be an improvement, you only publish a game when you know the game is going to be at least as good as your older game, not publish killing floor 2 which is so much worse than killing floor 1, i know this game can be something awesome in the end, but this is my review.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

KF2, albeit still in dev after its EA release back in April, is a really solid shooting co-op horror game. This installment does everything the first one did but just better: enhanced graphics, reviewed gameplay mechanics, even sexier dosh piles! It is very common for people hesitating to buy this game to wonder about its current early access state, and here is how I would ease you into buying it: The game doesn't really feel like it's in a beta, there are close to no bugs, the current content, judged at the moment minimal, will still take you on a 300h cruise and regular fixes plus dev posts makes you know this is going somewhere good.

The game makes you choose between 6 classes (at this time of writing, as there will be 10 in final release):
-Field Medic
-Berzerker
-Commando
-Support
-Firebug
-Demolitionist

Each of those have their know-hows and will require you to adapt to specific ways of playing the game, which diversifies it quite a lot. There are currently 6 very well-made official maps taking place in different post-apocaliptic settings, and 4 difficulties ranging from Normal to Hell On earth with a well-through design (the higher the difficulty, the quicker mobs get to you, rather than being even bigger HP sacks). I highly recommend this game to any co-op gamers out there!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I'm not gonna write a review, because I already had Martha Stewart's banana bread recipe copied... So I guess I'll just paste it.

INGREDIENTS

1/2 cup (1 stick) butter, at room temperature, plus more for pan
1 cup granulated sugar
2 large eggs
1 1/2 cups unbleached flour
1 teaspoon baking soda
1 teaspoon salt
1 cup mashed very ripe bananas
1/2 cup sour cream
1 teaspoon vanilla
1/2 cup chopped walnuts or pecans

DIRECTIONS

Preheat oven to 350 degrees. Butter a 9-by-5-by-3-inch loaf pan; set aside. In an electric mixer fitted with the paddle attachment, cream butter and sugar until light and fluffy. Add eggs, and beat to incorporate.
In a medium bowl, whisk together flour, baking soda, and salt. Add to the butter mixture, and mix until just combined. Add bananas, sour cream, and vanilla; mix to combine. Stir in nuts, and pour into prepared pan.
Bake until a cake tester inserted into the center of the cake comes out clean, about 1 hour 10 minutes. Let rest in pan for 10 minutes, then turn out onto a rack to cool.

TL;DR - Great co-op shooter. But slow development, unnecessary CS:GO & TF2 style microtransactions. Buy original KF or get KF2 on sale.

As someone who has clocked just under 200 hours on the original Killing Floor, I had high hopes for this game. However, I have a rather mixed view on Killing Floor 2.

Before I delve into the details of KF2; those new to the Killing Floor series, it is a co-op first person shooter where teams of up to six players combat against waves of 'ZEDs' with the goal of surviving all the waves and defeating a final boss. By killing ZEDs, healing players and surviving waves, the player is rewarded with money which is used inbetween waves to buy weapons, armour and ammo. To add to this, there are several perk classes which provides unique (and passive) abilities to players, these include commando, firebug, berserker, support specialist, etc. By using these perks and completing certain criteria, players level up in these perk classes and the benefits are increased. This could include more damage with perk class weapons, increased health and so forth. These can also be changed inbetween waves to allow players to adapt to various situations and playstyles, especially when playing as a team.

Now to the nitty gritty of KF2; the gameplay is a fun, fast-paced, gorefest with some some interesting new ZED types, a new final boss during the final wave and also with some brilliant visuals and sound design. KF2 also introduced several new features including sprint and weapon bash functions and the introduction of confiquring abilities for each perk class - which allows players to further tailor a class for their needs; i.e. abilities that benefit the player vs. benefits the team. These abilities include but are not limited to; supplying ammo to other players vs. increased ammo capacity and starting ammo for the player. It goes without saying that these new abilities do play a huge part in success on higher difficulties. This makes it an incredibly fun and exciting experience when you're running low on ammo and getting stormed by two Fleshpound's, a Siren and a small horde of lesser ZED types, and must solely rely on your team mates and quick thinking to survive.

However it feels lacking in contrast to it's predecessor - the charm of the British humor and voice acting which proved a humorous but distinctive feel to the original Killing Floor is lost on KF2. This may just be a personal view but I also feel the weapon and map variety is quite limited at this moment in time, however this could be changed upon full release, which brings me onto my next point.

Tripwire stressed it's point of doing 'Early access right', which I feel has been a monumental lie to it's fanbase. Since it's early access release in April 2015, it is still nowhere near it's full completion - instead of fixing bug issues, adding the remaining three classes (to a total of 10 perk classes), new maps and weapons, it has instead intergrated a 'ZED-Conomy' and microtransaction features - similar to those seen in CS:GO and Team Fortress 2. Considering a reward is often given it players upon completing a full match, in the form of a 'Crate' or 'USB' - to then make them pay for a 'Key' to unlock said items is an insult to players. However, on a positive note, these items are purely cosmetic and do not have an affect on the game.

Another feature added was a L4D inspired versus PvP mode, which in my own experience is a broken and unnecessary gamemode that doesn't fit in KF. Where teams of max leveled players will simply camp in one area and makes it virtually impossible to win when playing as ZED forces. This really killed my interest immediately. Finally, there is a myriad of other issues ranging from broken implentations of weapons and classes and nerfing of abilities as can be seen in full detail by other Steam reviews, to slow and infrequent updates and new content.

To summarize Killing Floor 2, it is not 'bad' game. However it is most certainly a fraction of what we have been told it is going to be. It is fun, gory and a great co-op experience, whilst the slow updates, bug issues and microtransactions do not break the game, when coupled with the asking price; it may be enough to turn you away. I would recommend purchasing the original Killing Floor, which not only is much cheaper and frequently on sale, but also still has a strong and active player and modding community, However, if you can stomach the flaws you may consider purchasing this when on sale in the future; however do check video reviews and the likes before purchasing to ensure this is a game for you.

Early Access Review

I loved Killing Floor and played it a lot (online, offline and even on LAN-Parties).
After they announced KF2 i was so happy it will get a remake.

Now they pushed there new patch adding a PvP Mode.
Sadly this kills KF2 for me. Why?

For me was KF never a PvP-Game, it was always about gathering with friend or random people and you have to work together beating waves after wave of monsters the game is throwing at you and then an awesome boss that needs teamwork and is just ultra hard to beat on yourself (on high difficulty nearly impossible)

Now Tripwire going the PvP way and not even given one single of the new player classes is just a cheap ripoff for the players that bought the game for PvE.

Sorry TripWire, i love your other games but KF2 for me is dying even it's still early access with the way you now going.
